positive.review:
[h1][b]‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ Finally, a game that lets me emotionally damage AND nurture digital monsters.[/b]

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
The battle system slaps harder than a freshly evolved MetalGreymon. It‚Äôs turn-based, but every move feels like solving a Rubik‚Äôs Cube that occasionally punches back. Timing, combo skills, and team synergy actually matter, no button mashing your way to glory here. You will learn strategy‚Ä¶ or perish trying.

[b]Digivolution Mechanic:[/b]
You don‚Äôt just level up, you raise your Digimon‚Äôs stats, personality, and sometimes their emotional stability (mine cries when I don‚Äôt feed it enough praise). Evolving isn‚Äôt permanent either; you can de-evolve to unlock new forms. It‚Äôs like Pok√©mon, but if your Charizard could go back to Charmander to rethink its life choices.

[b]Story & Writing:[/b]
Imagine a mix between a wholesome Saturday morning cartoon and a late-night anime that questions the nature of friendship. You read bedtime stories to strangers, help your Digimon understand human emotions, and occasionally stop a rogue AI from deleting your save file out of love.

[b]Graphics & Sound:[/b]
Bright, stylish, and nostalgic in all the right ways. The soundtrack goes from ‚Äúpeaceful digital meadow‚Äù to ‚Äúexistential techno crisis‚Äù in seconds, and somehow it works.

[i]My Digimon definitely understands me better than my therapist..[/i]

[h1][i][b]Digimon Story Time Stranger[/b][/i] may not be the greatest creature-collector/monster battle game but it is absolutely delightful for people who loves Digimon, potentially newcomers too.[/h1]

Hype is real for Digimon fans, while the game itself is awesome and it's probably the best Digimon RPG game up to date but it isn't perfect as it comes with some flaws. Excellent story writing, in the beginning it starts off slow and the plot can be quite confusing later on tho it'll get better, definitely worth to play until the end. The adventure gets a little dark at some point but not so much. Honestly I love the way they added Shadow Puppets as they narrate stories here, knowing they were made with real props just blew my mind. I also find some of the characters likeable. Decent gameplay with fluid animations, sometimes a little addictive however it can get repetitive and awfully grindy if you want to collect lots of Digimon. Visually looks nice but the amount of bloom effect makes everything looks somewhat blurry on highest settings, turning off "Bloom" option did not help for me. World designs are absolutely gorgeous, being able to travel between Digimon World and Earth is really fun. Pretty vast exploration although the maps are linear with many invisible walls around. There are outer-dungeons which players can discover, they are quite enjoyable to challenge and the best part is that you can get a free Digimon after beating the level. There is a mini-game about Card Battle but it's pretty much depends on luck. Digimon list are quite huge, some are rideable which is a great addition. Almost all characters are fully voiced, with exception of side stories' interactions and main character. The dub on default is English but changeable to Japanese. BGM sounds nice, the main theme [i]"wherever you are" by reche[/i] is so good it almost make me shed a tear.

Speaking of which, regarding the "awfully grindy part".. it kinda sucks that the digivolving system is highly dependant on Digimon's personality where players require to train them in the DigiFarm. Just don't go on blindly and then wonder why you can't get the lines correctly like me, because that's what happened when I got too excited and forgot about the way it works until many hours invested.. oh well, as long as everything did in correct order it should be fine. However it still can be felt like a chore as each training consumes time, hence the grindy part. The good part is that the Digimons in DigiFarm can earn EXP as well, however the inability to check digivolutions of respective Digimon in DigiFarm is a great flaw due to the hassle of removing and add them back again when requirements were not met, etc. I've also encountered a bug(?) where my main roster Digimons would get stuck somewhere of the map or simply not appearing at random times, which prevented me from riding any.

There is something that worth to take a note, if you're fond of [b]Black Agumon[/b] & [b]Black Garurumon[/b] evolution lines, you'll have to purchase the [u]Pre-order Bonus Pack DLC[/u] even if it just meant to unlock the lines. I personally pre-ordered the game earlier before release so I had no problems, however when I found out that for other people who did not purchase that DLC will be very disappointed. Most of the DLCs aren't really important unless you want more cosmetic options and/or quicker way to farm Digimons level and gold. Season Pass DLC seems to have a great potential for additional content and Digimon lines in future.

Overall the game is fun and it has been a good adventure for me, would love to come back to 100% it, hopefully next year. For the price it offers may not be justifying for some people so I'd  strongly suggest buying on sale. Recommended for both hardcore Digimon fans and anyone who is into creature-collector and monster battle games, can always give the demo a try if uncertain!

Digimon is back, and it's better than ever with Time Stranger!
In terms of time for 100%, it took me 100 hours and 2 playthroughs!

From the beautiful area design to the callbacks to various Digimon-related material sprinkled everywhere, it's like a dream come true. I found myself exploring, aiming to complete the field guide ASAP just so I could get a path to who I wanted. I even went about taking advantage of the DNA digivolution changes; you see, in CSHM we would only receive 1 piece of the fusion back upon breaking it down. Here, however, we receive both pieces, and honestly, it's quite an easy experience farm. I'm looking at you, Exveemon and Stingmon! The removal of the party size limit was like a dream; all that was required for you to be able to use the Digimon you wanted was story progression to complete more side quests! I also found myself not being particularly fond of how Digi-Ride was implemented into the game. Despite it being marketed as the go-to means of travel, it didn‚Äôt really feel faster than sprinting in most areas.

Great game.  Even if you didn't watch the show growing up and you're just sick of Pokemon putting out shit games, you'll enjoy this.  So many awesome looking mon to get in your team.  Highly recommend!

It's been 7 years since I wrote a game review, this game is my GOTY for 2025 and I decided I'd like to write a review on it. It's definitely worth getting. I'll start my review with the one negative, everything else is positive.

The Only Con: The grind. In any JRPG there is expected grind, but in this game there is still a lot of grind even if you purchase the DLC content which adds a dungeon that makes EXP & grinding much quicker. Digimon is grindy due to being able to digivolve and de-digivolve your digimon over and over again for the opportunity of boosted stats, and the game encourages this too. (I wrote this review before reaching the final evolutions & can say all the grinding was 100% worth it after reaching the final tier/ DNA Digivolutions)

Everything else is wonderful & the only times I found myself upset was when I fell behind on my grinding due to trying to zoom through the story quickly because the story IS AMAZING, but again this is my fault. The story was so so good that I couldn't help rushing.

It's not often that we get games that fully dive into time travel but this one goes in deeply in a way that is refreshing and with a new perspective that also quickly pulls you in & connects the Digimon & human worlds beautifully.

I often struggle with UI when first diving into a game and am directionally challenged. I had 0 problems with that in this game. The UI is easy to understand, the guides at the beginning are very engaging & helped me pick up on everything quickly. The navigation in this game is easy to understand too & I had no problems getting through zones too.

The VAing is amazing but I may be biased because I got super excited hearing Cristina Vee play Aegiomon, she will always be one of my favorite VAs of all time, she also voices my favorite character in Hunter x Hunter, Killua, so I'm probably biased. There was so much love breathed into this game at every single angle, including the VAing too.

I picked this game over the new Pokemon game and have 0 regrets. This game is everything that Pokemon needs to become imo. I love how the story director didn't shy away from discussing difficult and deep themes in this game such as grief and self doubt/ imposter syndrome and so much more. I cannot recommend this game enough and this is a must play.

The last Digimon game I played was Digimon World 3 and Digimon Rumble Arena so it's been a while. After this one I will definitely be catching up on the others.

My personal GOTY!

A delight from start to finish with multiple story beats that made me either tear up our straight up cry. :')
The games visuals are great, same with the models of the Digimon.

Music is good, but occasionaly the sound levels were a bit off, back when I played through it. Not much of a deal breaker though imo!

The voices are okay-ish. I played the game with English VO and most of the story characters were good. The digimon voices were on the weaker side though and often either had repeats amongst each other or used the same VA. Though I get that it wouldn't have been feasible considering the amount of Digimon there are. Luckily there are already some mods that try to fix that! :3

Gameplay-wise you got your standard monster collection thing going with usual turn based combat. Both very fun with some nice team builds you can have!

Costumes and music tracks being locked behind day 1 DLC sucks and may only be worth it when they're on a big sale. Those DLC dungeons might be fine, but I don't own them and I got through the game well enough without 'em!

Overall a very fun game and hopefully one of many great Digimon games to come out from here on out! (DLC looks promising :eyes:)
Go watch Beatbreak! Even the new Anime is great! ;p

Hands down the best Digimon game to date. If you haven't played Cyber Sleuth, these series of games have Persona vibes if you're familiar for comparison. Only downside is it completely lacks any multiplayer features, not even PVP elements like the previous title, but still better than any sad excuse of a Pok√©mon title that Nintendo can come up with these days.

A pretty good JRPG experience with monster taming flavor. A lot of work was put into Digimons and using them for battle, but it's quite clear everything outside of the core experience suffered from lower budget allocation, things like side-quests, which are quite simplistic or game trying to pretend it has unique gimicks in each dungeon, when they barely ever matter or are even completely fake and are just visual flavor.

Still, the main gameplay loop and campaign are enjoyable on their own and make the game worth recommending. I'm really hoping for some kind of expantion with new Digimons, new story and perhaps some upgrades to the side-content.

Really great turn based game. 
I love this type of games. This is a lot better then few years back. Voiceovers, world design, story...
Very nice Digimon game. It has the Cyber Sleuth spirit on it (which is a lot). The story so far is good and the digimons never looked better!
good game but would wish that the side quests should be more spraid instead of bunched at the end.

The best Digimon game ever made. It has everything Cyber Sleuth had, but better and with lots of QoL improvements. 
The only downside for me is that it‚Äôs missing some Digimons from Cyber Sleuth, and I would definitely love to see the full roster from Digimon Survive in the game.

Absolutely recommendmon.
Gameplay is what you would expects from 4 'mons in a row, great depth to the systems, cool synergies and plenty of options to have fun it. Grindingmon is there but it's not mandatory unless you're doing higher diffs or want to faceroll lower diffs (until a certain point). Plenty of sidequests and the vpet battles are while after a while tedious, still fun.
Visuals deliver, models are high quality, most environments especially in the digiworld feel lived in, hubs feel good to just wander around and interact with randomons.
Soundtrack is pretty good, there are a few memorable tracks, boss themes build the moodmon good, other BGM.
Story starts off a bit too slow, but if you bear with it long enough it delivers. Ending nails it perfectly, not too much complaint there.

It's a JRPGmon though, there are scenes that makes your eyes roll and a few parts overstay their welcome but those are worth to suffer trough for the story.

This might be one of the best modern Digimon games, Cyber Sleuth was good but had a lot of things that held it back, Time Strange fixed a lot of those issues, made a fun world to explore, and made it less of a yap fest (the voice acting helps). I haven't even finished the game yet, I have been doing the side quests because I want to experience more of this game.
My First digimon game. Addicting combat and digivolving. 100% worth the price. Runs well on Steam Deck.

Digimon Time Stranger can best be described as what you might get if Persona and Pok√©mon had a child‚Äîan engaging blend of creature-raising, character-driven storytelling, and strategic combat. This makes it an excellent entry point for players who may be unfamiliar with the Digimon franchise, as it combines familiar RPG elements with the unique charm and depth the series is known for.

For longtime fans coming from Digimon World on the original PlayStation, it‚Äôs important to clarify what this game is‚Äîand what it isn‚Äôt. If you‚Äôre searching for an experience that closely mirrors the classic PS1 game, with heavy micromanagement such as feeding, training, bathroom needs, and the life-cycle mechanics where your Digimon eventually pass away and reincarnate, you may find Digimon World: Next Order to be a closer fit. Next Order retains those traditional virtual-pet systems and focuses heavily on day-to-day care and partner maintenance.

Digimon Time Stranger, on the other hand, shifts toward a more story-driven RPG structure. While it still features Digimon raising and evolution, the emphasis is placed on narrative progression, party building, and strategic battles rather than constant micromanagement. It‚Äôs a more streamlined and accessible approach that allows players to spend more time exploring and engaging with the world while still feeling connected to their partner Digimon.

One standout feature is the presentation. The graphics in Digimon Time Stranger are impressively polished‚Äîarguably more visually striking than what we‚Äôve seen in recent Pok√©mon releases. The environments are vibrant, character models are detailed, and the overall aesthetic feels modern and thoughtfully crafted.

Whether you‚Äôre new to Digimon or a returning fan, Digimon Time Stranger offers a refined, stylish RPG experience that respects the franchise‚Äôs roots without being bound by them.

Just finished the game and I really loved it. Gameplay was fun, the story was great and there is also a lot of QoL compared to the previous Digimon Story Titles (Cyber Sleuth and Hackers Memory, but whats to expect with the time gap between the releases.) My big gripe just is that I wish we could chose our ride Digimon freely from the ones we own instead of having to have one in your party. (Also why doesn't Gallantmon come with Grani. I would've loved sitting on that thing like you can sit on Behemoth / Beelzemons Bike)

I wish TPC would put so much love and care into their games.
Amazing game, easily the best in the Digimon Story series.
Great game for newcomers and digimon fans alike. Fans of any monster catching games should definitely give this a go.

[h1]Is Digimon Time Stranger Worth Playing?[/h1]

Here are my thoughts on this game after completing it and doing almost everything optional in the game. Overall, Digimon Time Stranger was an extremely good game. There's tons of cool digimon to battle with, the battle system lets you choose the battle speed to be the speed you want and you can have super fast battle speed. There is multiple difficulty modes to choose from meanwhile the latest Pokemon games still have no option to select difficulty. The battles take a lot of strategy and the game is a ton of fun to play. A really cool addition in Digimon Time Stranger is for the first time in a Digimon game you can ride your Digimon as you explore areas in the game. Battles let you fight with 3 digimon at a time and guest party members as well. Only negative I can say about this game is the music could have been better. Digimon Story Time Stranger has way more depth then any pokemon game ever made, a way better story than any Pokemon game and it's overall a very good game.

Like other Story entries in the Digimon franchise, Time Stranger brings recollections of Persona, and REALLY expects you to do all of the side quests.  I will say that the second half of the game drags on for a while, companion digimon want to talk way too often, and needing a specific personality for DNA Digivolution is NOT an improvement, but these are minor complaints in the greater experience of the game.
Very good game, had lots of fun as my 1st Digimon game ,100% reccomand

Let me preface this by saying: Digimon Story Time Stranger is one of, if not the best game in the entire Digimon series, including games other than the Story titles

Not only the story is phenomenal, the gameplay is the culmination of everything the Digimon series strived to be, including game mechanics from a lot of the past Digimon Story titles that have been improved upon and make the game an enjoyable playthrough for Digimon fans and JRPG fans alike.

It was really engaging the whole way, the battle mechanics are the best they have ever been, no more long grindy sessions or random encounters that the past games have been know for, instead having a lot of friendlier and a lot less time consuming options to developing your dream team as watch the story.

And by the way, what a story! This is the first time in a while that I couldn't really predict the ending as I was pacing through it and it was a really emotional but somewhat light-hearted journey.

It's not all roses and rainbows though, I feel like there was some things that I wish were different:
For one, I think the way that they did the DigiFarms on this game is worse that earlier entries in the series, I didn't feel the need to engage with the DigiFarm until pretty much endgame when I needed to have certain personalities or stats for my Digimon to evolve, I kinda missed the DigiFarm being somewhere you had to return to, to see your Digimon developing and stuff, this game made it feel like an after-thought and not a main mechanic, which I didn't really like.

I also think that DigiRiding could've been better, not only it was somewhat limited on which Digimon could carry you (I still want to be princess carried by Lilithmon) but it wasn't really... needed? Like, there wasn't a really big map that I needed the DigiRide to explore and most of the maps that were somewhat bigger than most would have a ''stopping'' mechanic (like swinging on the Palmon vines) so it felt lackluster.

And a small gripe I've had with the game: missable (kinda) sidequests that you couldn't go back and do until almost the end of the game with ALMOST no warning (besides a not so helpful message from your Operator). It didn't REALLY affect my gameplay besides locking a stage of digivolution for a quest or two, but still, would've been better to have known before moving on that I couldn't access the sidequests that I hadn't done.

Overall Digimon Story Time Stranger is a FANTASTICAL game and I recommend anyone, even non-Digimon fans, giving it a try if you're not averse to JRPG Mechanics (and even then, I think it's still a pretty good game and worth at least watching the story). This is a true passion project and a worthy successor of the Digimon Story series!

The best digimon game so far for me. The story is linear but well structured, nice twist at the end and a really cool cinematic end fight. You can obtain a strong digimon without farming a lot, the music were pretty good and the animations of all the attacks were really well made. 
Just one flaw for me, when you approach the end of the story, a world of secondary quest opens and, for me, was just a bit too much. Other than that, really good game!

Despite not really connecting with the story, I had a lot of fun with Time Stranger. The gameplay loop is satisfying, although grinding for specific Digivolutions is tedious, but unlocking new Digimon and building a team was always the highlight for me.

I've played a lot of Digimon RPGs and this is definitely the best in terms of gameplay and polish imo. There's not much that really stood out to me, just a solid combat system and fun fights that reward exploring weaknesses.

I think the story and characters were a weak point, but the gameplay carried me through to the end. There were good moments, but overall I just struggled to connect with it. I know it's a highlight for some, so I'm willing to accept it just wasn't for me.

My first Digimon game and I screeched when my Patamon digivolved the first time. That's how Takeru must've felt back then. I thoroughly enjoy exploring the story and game and the nostalgia when seeing all my fave Digimon.

easily, *easily* the best digimon game ever made, it should say a real lot that it owned steam's front page for a day

if you havent played it and are considering playing it, play the demo, you wont regret it
Better story than Pokemon ZA. Its like they spent time to work on the story over the course of a few years.

The game is great if you're a Digimon fan, but it's mired in some questionable decisions by the devs. A good example of this is the new Digimon personality system, where from time to time, your Digimon partners will ask you questions you can respond to that will skew their personalities in one way or another. 

Normally, a system like this would be a fantastic breeding ground for fun and unique interactions with your Digimon, but you run out of dialogue choices within a handful of hours. Worse still, you can spend skill points your agent earns that boosts up the stats of Digimon with certain personalities, so if you're not careful going in, it's VERY easy to waste your skill points or have a wide spread of Digimon personalities that gain zero benefits because you just can't feasibly invest all your points into all of them to allow for that to be the case. Luckily, you can go into the Digi-Farm and relatively easily change personalities that way after a certain point, but that's a drain on in-game resources.

Speaking of the Digi-Farm, it's basically worthless and barely worth using most of the time, besides the aforementioned quick personality changes and min/maxing your Digimon stats in the late game, to get the Digivolution picks that you want. Which is unfortunate, because past games have done the Digi-Farm much better and it boggles my mind they couldn't just copy/paste those ideas. I don't think anyone would've complained about a better and more streamlined Digi-Farm here, even if it was a 1:1 copy.

The game also has a trading card game within it. It's very easy to collect the cards, but there's a ton of them and basically impossible to get them all without playing the mini-game attached to it with various NPCs several times in a row. The mini-game itself is fairly easy to grasp, but it's very slow and sometimes makes zero sense in the way the cards interact with each other. Funny enough, the game notes there's a presumably intentional bug in the game cards interact, that make Level 1 Digimon cards win every time with Level 7 Digimon cards, but it's possible to win (and lose) every interaction for no discernible reason whatsoever. It feels very tacked on to try to pad playtime.

Speaking briefly on other things, the graphics are fine enough (if most of the locations are on the boring side and you return to them multiple times), the music isn't fantastic and feels like amateur work for such a popular franchise, but at least the Digimon models and animations are very nice and haven't looked this good in a long time. It feels like they do the smart thing and with each new game they do a pass on each model and animation and try to make them a little better each time. I don't recall them being this good in Cyber Sleuth/Hacker's Memory, but then again, I haven't played those in quite a while.

Last but not least, the story is passable and doesn't do anything crazy. I'm also not a fan of the fact that the game railroads you incredibly hard. These are implied to be huge and interesting worlds, but I just don't get that feeling most of the time playing it. It has all the depth and breadth of a puddle in the street: from a distance, it may look like you'll fall into water up to your neck, only to discover by stepping in that it barely reaches your ankle. There's not a whole lot you can do, and very little reason to explore even when the few brief opportunities are afforded to you.

Someone mentioned in another review that it's one of the highest quality Digimon games ever made, and better than modern Pokemon games, its direct competition, and I agree completely on that sentiment. However, that bar is incredibly low these days, so it's no surprise Time Stranger easily vaults it. Unfortunately, if you compare it to any other modern RPG, especially with amazing games like Persona 5 (which this game feels like it's trying to emulate) and even Clair Obscur. it smacks face first into the bar and falls onto its back.

Still, I'm going to recommend it to people considering buying it because even though this game does a lot of things wrong (like beyond what's already mentioned, there's the crazy price point, yikes), it does a lot of things right too, and I want to see more Digimon games in the future with positive improvements. The potential is there, and I desire to motivate Bamco to invest in the series more.

Is really cool because there are tons of Digimon you can collect, train, and evolve, and it always feels like there‚Äôs something new to try. Building a team is super fun since you can mix different types and see what works best. The story is good, even if it slows down sometimes or a few places feel the same. But honestly, the huge variety of Digimon and how much freedom you get with them is what makes the game awesome, especially if you like RPGs and messing around with different monsters.

Absolutely incredible. Time Stranger takes everything from the already great Cyber Sleuth games and ramps it up to bring a stellar experience. The story, the music, the voice acting, the visuals, all in top form to keep you engaged throughout. Typical turn-based RPG gameplay is improved by adding a few tweaks like encouraging item use and the X-Arts. Interacting with your Digimon through conversation and following each digivolution path feels organic. All in all totally in love with this game. THE new gold standard for what creature collector games should be.
It's pretty much a great final fantasy game of Digimon, also if you are a fan of the old digimon games this is the game to get!

Best Digimon game that we've ever gotten in my opinion. They took everything from Cyber Sleuth and improved upon it. The combat, the exploration, and story all got big upgrades! I definitely recommend this to someone who is interested in Digimon but has never played any of the games before and for Digimon fans! Can't wait for the DLC episodee!

I've been a fan of Digimon for a long time, yet I haven't played a Digimon game since Digimon World Dawn on the Nintendo DS! Getting back into it was an absolute blast as a fan, but I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys turn by turn combat with great complexity and a heavy focus on a compelling story. This was a 10/10 experience for me, so much so that after clearing the game, I want to continue playing!

As someone who is a long time Digimon fan and a fan of the Olympus XII, this game was very satisfying to play. While I don't consider the story as great as Cyber Sleuth and Hacker's Memory, it's still enjoyable and the gameplay is very much an improvement from the previous two games. 

Very much a recommend buy.
Best Digimon Game so far. I enjoy it. digivolutions feel like a "whos that pokemon?" situation when unlocking forms for the first time.

Definitely a 8/10 
A great Digimon game but honestly could've have been better.
The world feels alive since every NPC also progresses through the story with you,
sadly they are not as memorable as Cybersleuth or Hacker's memory.
gameplay is addicting, and each digimon have great model.
i hope the success of this game will make the next digimon story even better.

Another good entry for the Digimon Series. Nice graphics, great music and a story, which I thought at the beginning to be not that interesting, but redeemed itself with a bittersweet cool ending.

Some nice details:

- Each digimon has his own signature attack with it's own animation.
- The Digiworld feels more alive thanks to putting a great variety in the overworld.
- Your Digivice is a fucking gun!

Things which should/could have been better:

- Unlike the previous games I didn't really find a good farming spot for Exp etc. which is surely thanks to the Exp/Money/Material DLC. In both complete playthroughs (Hard and Mega+) I only got a total of 5 random encounters which can have the mons who give a bunch of extra EXP/Money/etc.
- The pacing felt a bit off to get to Mega-Level Mons etc. but that's probably due to the game already being easy. If you get the stronger Mons sooner it would be even easier.

As a long-time Digimon fan, I'm very happy that Digimon is making a come back now with Digimon Story Time Stranger. This is an amazing game, and is a huge improvement over the last Digimon Story game, Cyber Sleuth.

The visual and detail is great, the new mechanics are a relief, the music is nice, the character is memorable, and especially, the story is awesome! Digimon isn't afraid to feature stories for adults (there are themes of loss, death, and regret), which, ahem, Pokemon certainly wouldn't dare to do. I was captivated by the story of this game, and even thought deeply about it several times. So I think even if you're not a fan of monster-taming games, you can still enjoy this game as an RPG with a deep story.

The game's story itself is quite long, taking around 50-60 hours to complete. If you want to 100% the game, it might take around 80-100 hours. Unfortunately, I don't think the game has much endgame content (I hope in the next game, they can think of more end game content.). After completing the main story, you'll just be stuck with side quests or dungeons that aren't very interesting. Even the New Game Plus itself doesn't offer anything new. No new bosses or anything like that.

One thing that deserves praise from this game is that the developers weren't stingy with their budget. Nearly 90% of the main story scenes have voice actors (and for the first time, they're fully in English). Compare that to Pokemon, which still doesn't have voice actors to this day! Furthermore, in some segments, they even created real wayang (shadow puppets) and didn't use CGI. They truly treat this game as art, and I think that's highly commendable.

However, the game does have its flaws, which I think are worth pointing out as feedback to the developers. First, while I'm glad Digimon now has English voice actors, there are some characters that I don't think fit the characters they portray (for example, Merukimon). Then there's the DLC system, which isn't consumer-friendly. Ultimate Edition buyers felt it especially when they suddenly received another DLC on day one that wasn't included in the ultimate edition. This was, of course, incredibly frustrating (please don't be so greedy). On a small scale, for example, the Digi Farm system is annoying because we have to leave the Digi Farm to evolve digimon.

Despite those flaws, overall, I really enjoyed this game. I hope Digimon can continue to maintain this level of quality in their games.
Great game, improves already established Digimon Story systems and implements new ones. Good story. Graphics look great. Very nice soundtrack. Very smooth gameplay experience

Came into this game with not many expectations, altho I heard a lot of good about it.

Say to day I've loved every moment I have play it.
Story is really well done, doesn't feel like a drag in any areas minus one kinda late game puzzle that was very back and forward talking to progress it. but it wasn't overly that bad.

The amount of digimon to have is a great range as well, there is more I want to say but with specifics that could spoil progressional things. so I won't. Over all it's really amazing, worth the price tag and plenty to do and very fun to simply replay.

For Digimon Fans: This is probably one of the strongest Digimon RPGs in recent memory. If you love collecting Digimon, evolving them, and building deep bonds, there‚Äôs a lot here to like. The presentation, monster roster, and systems are solid, and many of the story beats land well.

For JRPG Players / Newcomers: It‚Äôs a mixed bag. The core gameplay is robust, but pacing issues, repetitive dungeons, and some mechanical quirks (fast travel, frame rate) could put off players looking for a very streamlined experience. If you‚Äôre patient and enjoy long-form monster-raising RPGs, it‚Äôs worth a look.

Overall: Very good, but not perfect. It‚Äôs ambitious and often succeeds, especially on the monster-collection front.

I only recommend the game to fans of Digimon, if you aren't a fan or at least a little interested in Digimon there are definetly far better JRPG's out there that I would reccomend over this one at least at full price. 

Digimon Time Stranger is definitely a step forward from Cyber Sleuth in terms of graphics, enviroments and overall polish, being able to walk through towns and seeing Digimon just doing their thing around you is amazing and makes those areas really feel alive, also having voice acting for most of the lines and for I think every Digimon  when they get taken out or use their signature move (All of which have unique animations) is impressive when other JRPG's are seeming satisfied with just a text box. I'm happy to have this as a new standard for the series.

Now for the reason I wouldn't reccmend it to a typical JRPG fan, the side content is pretty lackluster and most of it is dumped on you towards the end of the game. Most side quests come down to go somewhere, beat a digimon then go back, there are some that are more interesting but the majority are over pretty quickly. There are some small mini-games even card collecting/battling that falls a bit short in terms of it's actual gameplay but other then those you're going to be just battling most of the time. 

The battle system is fine pretty much the same as Cyber Sleuth, you have 3 Digimon on the field 3 in reserve and 3 additional Digimon that may join depending on the story although most of the time it will will just be Aegiomon (RIP my all hot babe Digimon Team) and while the attack animations are great the 5x speed option helps a lot when you've already seen them. Similar to Cyber Sleuth, most of the strategy comes down to the paper/scissors/rock type advantage, also like the previous games most bosses are immune to status effects so they become useless quickly which can make Team building feel a little pointless this is exacerbated by the fact they removed Digimon unique abilities instead adding a bunch of generic ones linked to the personality system.

This is my biggest issue with the game, every digimon can have any ability, can be equip with any 4 moves and any 2 items, can have their stats maxed at 9999 so the only thing that makes them unique in terms of gameplay are the signature move/s, a lot of which are very similar to each other, so while it's great literally any Digimon can beat the game it loses a lot in terms of strategy and player expression in team building. 

To end on a good note, I like the added skill tree and the new farm system both streamlined a lot of the annoying systems in the previous games, getting Bond, talent & Digivolution requirements is so much easier (although I still spent way too long micromanaging my farm until I found out trained stats don't carry over on evolution), now if only they didn't take the digivolve option out of the farm menu.

a tad bit too expensive, a 10% discount should be more fair. Regardless one of the best digimon game. Although there's a slight bug idk if it's only me but everytime there's a notification (operator speak or just anything) the game just decide to cut ANY input at all and freeze what currently you put, usually movement like camera or your character movement.

It's not annoying if it happened once or twice but the fukng operator won't shut the f up EVERY SINGLE TIME there's any event unfolding before your eyes, like STFU BTCH holy sht. Since the movement bug only appear when there's notification and the operator can't shut her windpipe this bug occur quite often and get super annoying on certain time. It's the only 1 reason i hate about this game

Edit :
Scratch that, add 1 more thing i hate about this game, the side mission. It's not bad, but the moment you get them. LITERALLY and i'm not even joking, LITERALLY almost like 20 or 30 side quest are only unlocked when you're in the final dungeon in which you can't even call it dungeon because how linear it is. Like come on bruh, you can't spread the side quest throughout the story at all? Like seriously?

A bit annoying but regardless my stand on the price still the same, worth it but when it's slightly discounted

Really good game if you're a Digimon fan or a JRPG kinda fan, tons of cool Digimon with a great glow-up in the models since the last games, and the world and environment seems very colorful, very full of life too. Solid gameplay and story, some good messages interwoven as well. I'm definitely looking forward to what the future holds with this game.

Overall, its a great jrpg with monster catching elements. If you played digimon dawn/dusk or cybersleuth, you will definitely enjoy this one as well.

Pros:
1. 475 digimon so the roster is quite vast so you quite a selection
2. 4 personalities and their buffs allow for some interesting strategies if your not doing Mega +. Unfortunately I could not finish my Mega+ run due to a game breaking bug. Data vs virus vs vaccine and the elemental combinations makes it easier or harder depending on how you abuse the systems given
3. The story while it does have some cheesy dialogue at points, overall the story was really good and the foreshadowing was implemented very well.
4. Side quests are all done pretty well, they try to mix it up so not all the side quests are the same

Cons:
1. Minor thing but the texture quality is some of the early game areas is a bit lackluster compared to the areas in the later games, but you can tell their vision.
2. There needs to be a better bug report system or lack of one. Some players encounter game breaking bugs and their only choice is to load a previous save or start over if they accidently overwritten their save like me. Noteable huge gamebreaking bugs are in the Factory and Junomon Temple. When you get to the quest marker sometimes the next quest doesnt trigger, but you can interact with the next quest objectives. If you do, you are just stuck when the quest actually triggers.
3. Walking up ladders and stairs are done on 1/2 walking speed for some reason. Also whenever you interact with something, it usually cancels digiride, so you have to digiride again afterwards
4. There are  several points in the story where you have to walk, teleport, walk and repeat just to pad game time.

Overall the games a 9/10, however the lack of slid bug report makes it 8/10. I would wait for them to do a few more rounds of bug fixes before picking the game up.

Edit: Another Con I forgot to mention is that you can't bulk use items. Example: when feeding you digimon in digimon farm you have to feed 1 item at a time and when yu have to do this 50 times to get bond to 100% for one digimon gets tedious.

Amazing game. The best Digimon game i have played out of any that has been released over the last 10 years. The only game that comes close to this one in the franchise is the OG Digimon World 1 for nostalgic and sentimental reasons (Personal opinion). The storytelling is A-tier. The gameplay and combat is great as well. I was never really a fan of turn-based combat in other games, but the beautiful and estatic animations made me change my opinion on it, there simply is not a single thing that i would change about it. Bandai has made a game that really made a mark in the Digimon franchise and i hope they make the future games just like this one. Quality game that i can recommend to any Digimon fan. 10/10
Fantastic game. If you have any love for monster collecting, digimon, or JRPGs like the SMT series, you'll find something you love here!

Finally, a monster collector game that's about saving the entire time-space continuum, not just zoning out a city block! While others are stuck designing their perfect urban park layout, Time Stranger lets me evolve a giant metal dinosaur to punch the actual fabric of reality back into place.
Great story, awesome fusion mechanics, and my starter didn't get stuck doing construction work.
P.S.: Digimons have a better Mega forms than Pokemon ever designed theirs.
10/10 Would recommend the game for those who swore their life to Pokemon (me included)
Price? Best game I spent over 100e on! Won't spent a penny to get Pokemon ZA tbh.

Coming from someone who's played the Cyber Sleuth duology (on Switch) and has been waiting for years: Time Stranger is a HUGE step up! More focus on the Digimon overall which I feel the Cyber Sleuth games lacked, tons of new QOL features that will make NG+ less daunting, proper love for international audiences with a great English dub and multiple language options... It's clear that the developers love Digimon as much as the fans do.

Even at full price I'd say this game is worth it. But you can always count on future sales if you want, unlike a certain other monster-catching franchise. ;^)

As of writing this review I haven't beaten the game, but I felt the need to write this review anyways. If you enjoy the Monster Catching genre in any way shape or form this game is near the peak of the genre. Intricate skills that let you min max to your hearts content, to a varying selection of difficulties that let you play to your hearts content in any way you want. 
Mind you I bought this as a Pokemon die hard fan. Never skipped any of the games (till the recent one). This game surprised me with its detail to its monsters (digimon). Get it. Buy it. Enjoy it. Its peak for its genre. Its worth the price (69.99 base USD or 93.49 CAD)
Better than other monster catching and battling games released this year.

This is the best Digimon game made, I think. Realistically, it's probably a 9/10, it's not without its faults,(some weak dungeons, some weak characters, easy digifarm) but... personally, it gets a 10/10 from me. I loved every second.

It's absolutely incredible. If you're a fan of Digimon, you owe it to yourself to give it a go.

Absolute cinema of a game. Time Stranger was perfect in nearly every way, gameplay mechanics, depth, story telling, voice acting, soundtrack, and character development. The price of $70 is a lot nowadays, so if this game goes on sale, pull the trigger, but even so, it is very worth it. About 60-70 hours to beat the game if you take your time to soak it in and explore, building your Digimon team and roster and completing side quests (which is recommended as it increases your Agent Rank). Even after beating the game in about 70 hours, I fully plan to replay in Mega+ difficulty (new game plus basically) as well as complete the field guide and grow my main team. As for gameplay quality, if you played previous Digimon Story titles, Time Stranger makes many QoL improvements, such as no more random encounters, speeding up battles, transitions between menu screens and battles, quest direction, story pacing, and art direction. Fully recommend this game for both Digimon fans and people that have never played before but enjoy turn based RPGs. 10/10.

üíæ 40 Hours In ‚Äì and I Can‚Äôt Stop Playing

I was gonna wait until I actually finished the game before writing this,
but after 40 hours, I just can‚Äôt. I‚Äôll edit it later, but I need to talk about this right now.

This is honestly one of the best (if not the best) creature collector RPGs I‚Äôve played in a decade.
I don‚Äôt even wanna mention the mess that Pokeyman has turned into, but Digimon Time Stranger might‚Äôve just dethroned it ‚Äî gameplay, story, voice acting, straight-up fun ‚Äî all of it.

If you love Pokeyman but feel let down by what the series has become, try this game.
You‚Äôll end up wishing Pokeyman could be even half as good as this.

üíÄ The Charm of Digimon

People who‚Äôve never played Digimon always say:

‚ÄúMan, those designs are weird, I wouldn‚Äôt play that.‚Äù

Yeah ‚Äî that‚Äôs the point.
That‚Äôs the charm.

You start with a little blob.
Then it turns into a bigger blob with teeth.
Then a dinosaur.
Then a literal child.
And then the Anti-Christ.

It‚Äôs ridiculous, unpredictable, and so much fun.

Every time you evolve, you‚Äôve got like 3‚Äì5 possible evolutions, and most Digimon have around 6 stages total, so you can go down completely different paths each time.
And yeah, you can even evolve backward ‚Äî it makes sense when you play, I promise.

If you‚Äôve got a team of 6, technically you could end up having almost the whole 400+ Digimon roster just through all the different paths.
Sounds overwhelming, but it‚Äôs not. You can‚Äôt really screw yourself over or get softlocked. It‚Äôs just really fun to mess around and experiment.

‚öîÔ∏è Combat System

Combat is classic ‚Äúweakness/resist‚Äù stuff, but way more in-depth.
You‚Äôve gotta think about not just what you‚Äôre strong or weak against, but also if your own type (which is separate from your move types) can even hit for effective damage at all.

There‚Äôs a third mechanic that shows up later in the game ‚Äî you can kinda ignore it at first ‚Äî but it adds a nice twist.

Damage can go from like x0.3 (basically nothing) to x4.5, which feels insanely good when you line it up right.
It‚Äôs that dopamine hit when you see ‚Äúx4.0‚Äù pop up.
Figuring out weaknesses is part guessing, part logic ‚Äî kinda like the ‚ÄúOne More‚Äù system from Persona.

And don‚Äôt worry, the difficulty can be chosen from Easy to Normal and Hard.
There‚Äôs a fourth and fifth one too, but these seem to be locked at the start.

üìñ Story & Progression

Story-wise?
Pretty damn good. Not mind-blowing, but really solid.
Compared to Pokeyman though? God-tier.

I‚Äôm about 40 hours in, maybe 75% through the main story, with a bunch of side quests still to go.
You‚Äôve got your MC rank, which goes up as you complete quests, and that affects how far you can evolve your Digimon.

So yeah, do the side quests ‚Äî they‚Äôre fun, they tie into the main story, and they give more context to the world.
And one would assume there‚Äôs endgame content ‚Äî I can‚Äôt wait to get my ass handed to me.

I actually like how the evolution system is kinda gated by your progress.
It sounds restrictive but it‚Äôs not ‚Äî it actually pushes you to experiment more instead of rushing to Mega form right away.

‚ù§Ô∏è Final Thoughts

I love this game.
Like, really love it.
Can‚Äôt wait to jump back in after posting this.

All in all ‚Äî just get this game already.
It‚Äôs genuinely great and you won‚Äôt regret it.

Have fun ‚Äî and yeah‚Ä¶ there‚Äôs a reason it‚Äôs sitting at 90% positive.

‚úÖ TL;DR

Deep combat that actually makes you think

Wild, creative evolutions that feel unpredictable in the best way

Genuinely engaging story

Tons of Digimon variety and options

You can‚Äôt really mess up ‚Äî just experiment and have fun

10/10 would get digivolved and wrecked again.

Tl;dr The best Digimon game I've played yet. The visuals are modern, if unimpressive, the dialogue and pacing are much better then the other Stories games, and combat is snappy and satisfying. However, it's very clearly a budget title and should be priced accordingly. $50 USD would be understandable. $70 is absurd.

Full review:
  Oh how I wish these Digimon games were properly priced. First we get a slew of hd ports of old PS Vita games for $60, now we get a clearly budget title for $70. 
  However, I'm still giving this a thumbs up for when I eventually get it on a sale, it's definitely worth $50 or less, because it actually is a great Digimon title.
  It's come a long way since Cyber Sleuth, with much better pacing, better dialogue, and a more immediately exciting and interesting story. Gone is the onslaught of neverending, rambly text. 
  The combat is also much snappier, helped along by modern jrpg mechanics like attacking enemies on the field for an advantage (and enemies being on the field in the first place), as well as smoother animations and a quick battle end recap. 
  The visuals are the first with things like lighting effects and shadows in a Digimon game, in that tride and true anime shaded style. It looks very appealing, even if more like an early PS4 title.
  I almost kept this game at the $70 price tag, because I really was having a lot of fun and it is absolutely the best overall Digimon game I've played (though I have a soft spot for Digimon World Next Order). It's just not a $70 game by any means.

Overall Rating: Good Genre Game (Monster Collection JRPG)

I absolutely love this game. The Digimon game we all have been waiting for and wanting for so long. 

The roster of Digimon is large, making it so you'll sometimes struggle to pick and choose who you want on your team of 6. With varying lines of evolution, making it interesting and fun to see how your Digimon partners change. With the balance of Vaccine, Data and Virus being the main typings, makes it understandable to figure out type weaknesses and strengths, to set up a good team to handle most boss fights. 

Story is incredibly good, the characters and digimon all have believable reactions, attachments and personalities. Making the world feel more real and immersive. The plot is interesting and makes you want to learn more, and keep playing. 

The auto battle toggle makes grinding feel smooth and less of a chore, when you want to level up your digimon or work towards a specific evolution line. 

With how many Digimon you can have at a time in your box being so high, makes you feel no pressure in wanting to explore or try different digimon lines. Or even having multiple of the same digimon, if you want to keep an evolution stage from one of the lines. And you can switch them out at anypoint in the game, not having to go to a specific place to swap your team around. 

While the game has been compared to Pokemon, I can agree it has some similar aspects. But the combat and understanding of reactions and types, is far better. I also would venture to say Digimon has a far more emotionally mature standard to it, with its story and designs within the franchise. 

I highly recommend playing this game if you love Digimon, or are new to Digimon. The gameplay and story are fun, and the model designs are incredibly well made.
fun story and really  nice evolution paths

This would be my comeback to a Digimon game after a very long time, and I am very happy and refreshed!

I played and loved the demo of Time Stranger. The story up to this point feels compelling with a lot of surprises. Very much enjoyed the vivid graphics, animations, and victory poses of each Digimon!! Loved strolling around Tokyo, the train stations in this game are somehow very neat and detailed. Loved how lively Central Town is in every era :)

Raising Digimon is fun. Digivolving, de-digivolving, training, and finding the right combination is fun.
I don't really get the personality system yet but it's nice being able to talk to them and affect their stats.
I was very surprised with the scale of Digimons. Some of them are apparently HUGE, and can be SCARY. Digiride is GOAT. It has been a dream to ride a Digimon. They're generous too with the ride poses and details! Cute.

There are a lot of convenience such as the battle speed adjuster, auto battle (never used but it's there), I also loved the feature where you can easily continue training at Digifarm with just a click.

What I don't like the most so far is the sound mixing(?) because BGM can be so faint, and sometimes the voice acting of EN dub (sorry) just doesn't fit. I also don't like the hollowness when a Digimon makes a motion but it is soundless; it feels flat.
The card minigame feels 'eh', but I can still enjoy the sprite animation and collecting the cards.
This one is not really a complaint but the 'hard' mode turns out to be merciful.

Let's see how it goes from here.

As a digimon fan since childhood I was HYPED for this and it did not dissapoint.

Its everything Cyber Sleuth was but better, and probably the most polished Digimon Game to date.
Its defnitly my new favorite of the Monster Taming Genre, and if this genre interests you at all this game is worth checking out, even if you are not into the digimon-franchise otherwise.

The story takes a bit to get going, but once it does it will HOOK you. Its also fully voice acted.

The artstyle great, and the digital world feels super lively. Human world is fine too but clearly was not the focus

The most fun part is definitly the team-building, because of the branching digivoltution parts and the option to digivolve up and down at will once single mons has sooo many differenr forms it can end up in. Each digimon has its own special attack with its own little animation.

The boss fightes are always a highlight, and on the higher difficultys pack quite the punch. Especially at Mega+ you have to strategize and but some effort into team-building, because only going in with your heaviest hitters is not going to cut it

This was my first time ever having any real contact with the Digimon series. I never had the opportunity to watch the anime when I was a kid, I was always more of a Pok√©mon fan (mostly because of the show) and played a bunch of those games growing up, so Digimon Story: Time Stranger was something completely new for me.

I actually decided to get the game because so many people were saying good things about it. Day by day or maybe week by week, I kept hearing more praise and started getting more and more interested until I finally gave in. And honestly, I‚Äôm glad I did, because it‚Äôs truly an amazing experience.

I haven‚Äôt had this much fun playing a ‚Äúcreature collector‚Äù game in a long time. The gameplay is addictive, the world and story are interesting, and even though I still don‚Äôt remember the names of most Digimon, they all feel unique and full of personality. I don‚Äôt have a favorite Digimon yet since I haven‚Äôt collected them all, but maybe I‚Äôll find one when the time comes.

It‚Äôs been a refreshing and fun experience overall, familiar in some ways, but different enough to stand on its own. For someone who grew up with Pok√©mon, Digimon Story: Time Stranger was the perfect way to finally explore this universe, and I‚Äôm really glad I didn‚Äôt skip it!

Absolutely amazing game, I never quite got off the ground with the other Digimon titles but this one does so many things right and better than I expected it is now a favourite game, period.

Amazing Music, More than decent graphics, complex and compelling story, loads of fun with learning about all the Digimon, evolving and combining them.

Absolutely brilliant, an absolutely huge step up from Cyber Sleuth in basically every way, plays like a dream, wonderful story, lots of excellent digimon choices. Couple of very minor issues re balance of digimon types but thats a tiny little thing.

‚úÖ Game has an amazing story that is worth playing for it
‚úÖ Massively improved sequel to Cyber Sleuth
‚úÖ Collecting and discovering Digimons is really fun
‚úÖ Boss battles are extremely challenging which I liked
‚úÖ Can use items without wasting a turn (why didn't anyone thought of this idea before?)
‚úÖ Massive skill tree to unlock

After grinding this game and getting achievements, I can say that this game is goated as fuck! I've been itching for a good monster tamer kinda game and this game delivered! 

Only thing I'd need to say is that some things like the digifarm and transfering stats while digivolving are a bit underexplained (either that or I'm an absolute buffoon), but it doesnt stop the game from being good.

oh and don't buy the dlcs/season pass until we know what they give, as much as I love both agumon and garumon, I don't think a 5$ dlc is worth it to get them as a virus variant
honestly, this has became my favorite digimon game, if you're curious and wanting to dive into the series you can start right here in digimon story: time stranger. Goodluck Tamers

INCREDIBE. GAME! 100x better than Legends ZA. So disappointed in lackluster, boring, LAZY pokemon games lately. This was a an exciting and refreshing change in the monster-collection genre! This was my first time EVER buying a full price, $70 game after experiencing the crushing disappointment of Pokemon Legends ZA! It was so worth it!

Combat exciting and fun, love the move change system
Love the ease with which you digivolve/de-digivolve to try out all kinds of skill sets/digimon
Storyline is EXCELLENT*** with plot twists and great character development
Art is awesome and the world is alive (exceptionally better than ZA!)

Two issues stand out to me. 
1. Can't preview clothing in the shop, and there should be MANY more cosmetic options for outfits. 
2. When taking on side missions, you see an icon on the region-changing menu (like when you travel to another region,) to inform you which region you must go to, however you do NOT see any indication while using the travel system WITHIN a region. So you travel to new region where the quest exists, then you get on the region traveling flying mount (birdmon pegasusmon etc.) but then you do not see where in the region you must go to continue the quest. So you can travel to the opposite end of the region and start looking for the quest, only to find it on the opposite side. This is probably my biggest issue with the game. 

The game is INCREDIBLE despite these minor flaws. Great work!
The story for this game is super amazing and the best Digimon game ever. If you have always wanted to try out Digimon this is an amazing starting point or right after Digimon cyber sleuth.

The game has been amazing and is truly filled with so much love for the franchise, its been an endless great experience. A blast to play and has reenergize my love for Digimon!! Can't wait to fully complete my run and then 100% :D

A lot of fun, and worth the price. Really reminds me of Persona blended with Pokemon. This is my first Digimon game, and I've only really watched Digimon Adventure, 02, and the Movie (2000). I've fairly stringy with buying games that cost more than $50 and especially games with Denuvo, but to me, Digimon was worth it.

Subjectively speaking, the bonding aspect was the best part. It's one of the things I enjoy in Pokemon and was glad to see a more fleshed out version. It really culminated in the credits scene and the call back to each of my main digimon. The human characters were okay, especially the protagonist. I felt like they were a third-wheel, but ultimately the story resolved itself nicely. Combat was fun, but could certainly be improved upon.

I'll certainly keep an eye out for future Digimon games as a result of Story Time Stranger.

I really enjoyed the game a LOT!

Such a breath of fresh air compared to the usual "Pokemon style formula" that many creature collection games tend to follow! This was my first time playing a Digimon game since the OG Digimon World on PS1 and giving this game a go did not disappoint - pretty much the exact opposite!

The game was a bit grindy at times which I normally dislike, but it felt very rewarding: You don't capture the monsters in here like you do in most creature collector games, but you have to defeat that said monster enough times to digitalize it into your ally! This way of "capturing" your companion creatures felt really rewarding to me and made the grind feel much more fun! The main gameplay overall felt fun for me!

The story was much more serious and definitely for a more mature audience, dipping into very dark themes and territories at times, which I (as an adult gamer) really appreciated! Sure it's fun to play less serious games that are more suitable for a younger audience but I realized that it really made the game stand out even more among it's fellow creature collectors! I hope we'll see more creature collectors that are aimed for a more mature/adult audience! The story itself wasn't really anything super extraordinary and the writing felt clunky at times, but then again; I did not pick this game up for it's story and I think most people won't either.

The art style was pretty nice and I liked that how much personality they had put into the different Digimon! The Digiworld was much nicer visually than the human world: The human world felt really bland and barren and it was really off putting how non important people didn't even have a face. Digiworld was much better though!

I finally completed the game. The only achievement I have yet to do is complete the game on Mega+ difficulty which I will probably get. It took me roughly 54 hours to beat the game on Hard and I was stuck on two boss fights halfway through the game. I'll go over what I enjoyed and what I personally disliked [b]a lot[/b]. Strap yourselves in.

[b]This review will contain spoilers in regards to the story. If you wish to not read it, a TL;DR will be provided below.[/b]

[h1]The Positives[/h1]
- The game has a really solid main story that hooks you immediately, thanks to the grand opening this game has to offer with the Shinjuku Inferno. The characters are likable and the main cast of characters were well written. I could feel the bond between Inori and Aegiomon like they were actually siblings together. The overall story felt like I was watching an anime and it felt even more like that during the 2nd half of the game.
- The balance of the game is different from the last one where the passives are now depending on the Digimon's personality. This allows for extremely flexible team compositions where you end up running with more than just 6 digimon in your party, you'll swap and adjust to what fits your team and playstyle best, especially when there's over 400 digimon you can use.
- The combat is great with the quality of life changes if we compare it to CyberSleuth. A lot of quality of life changes have been implemented (such as items no longer using up your turn during combat) and adjusted the combat/animation speed from 1x up to 5x if you so desire. Everything the game threw at me in those fights felt fair and just, even if two particular boss battles were particularly tough.

[h1]The Negatives[/h1]
- First things first, I am not a fan of the linear progression. The game looks gorgeous and yet I can not move freely around. It's a little disappointing that I just can't explore the world of Iliad freely, that world looks astonishing in every way possible. If this allowed me to roam around freely, I'd be heads over heels for what has been given to us.
- Aegiomon, once you have him, will always be by your side, fighting alongside you whether you like it or not. Personally, I wish there was an option that allowed me to have him join my fights or not as controlling 4 Digimon in one fight made things ridiculously easy at times, especially considering that I can just slap Aura and Revive on him and he'll always become the best support Digimon one could ask for as he scales really well compared to your own Digimon.
- A lot of the boss battles are, unfortunately, immune to most status effects. This makes most fights slap-stick fights where you buff your team up with defensive skills rather than using statuses to come up with a proper strategy.
- Grinding. The game demands that you at times backtrack to level up your digimon or make a new team as some of those boss fights, especially early on in Iliad, are absolutely brutal because of the limited resources you have. Roughly [b]4 hours[/b] of my gametime was dedicated to making a new team after Parrotmon and Titamon wiped the floor with my favorite digimon, making me to go out of my way to get new ones for a favorable matchup.
- And of course, the price and the DLCs that are unnecessarily shoved in there. 70 bucks is a staggering amount of money. Just wait for a sale.

These are all however personal or skill issues I have had with the game. I am a massive Pokemon fan and I enjoyed the last Digimon Story game a lot and this one is not a let down. It kinda lived up to my expectations, something that Nintendo hasn't done since Black/White. I think there is a lot of room for improvement but considering what I expected from a Digimon Story game, I am satisfied. I hope future Digimon games get better with each release as I am infatuated with them.

TL;DR: The game is good. Wait for a sale as 70 bucks is a lot or just buy at full price if you liked the previous Digimon Story game. It's worth it.

**Summary**
---------------
4/5 Stars
Time Stranger is a fun but simple RPG.
Wait for a sale to purchase it.

**General**
--------------
"Digimon Story: Time Stranger" is a Japanese Role Playing Game set in the near-future world of science fiction. While Digimon are certainly central to the plot, the beginning of the game focuses on your role as a time travelling agent. Digimon are more a means to an end until you reach the middle of the game and see how the Digimon interact with one another. The core story is about how the horrors of digital warfare affect the deutragonist, Inori.

**Reasons to Purchase Time Stranger**
--------------------------------------------
This is the first Digimon console game that can be universally agreed upon as good. Digimon World is regarded as the best Digimon experience, but is frustrating for beginners. Digimon Cyber Sleuth revived Digimon video games (outside of Japan) but ingrained Kowloon into our minds forever. 
Time Stranger has detailed environments, decent combat, is simple to follow, and the mechanics are par the course for gaming standards.

The artwork is stupendous. You can find a series of development videos on YouTube wherein the developers discuss and showcase step-by-step the care and effort they put into modelling the Digimon. The lead artist for the humans is Suzuhito Yasuda, who you may recognize from Devil Survivor and Durarara.

You can buy most Digimon skills from the shop, so you no longer need to level up all the way like previous games to learn every single skill (It's still best to do so for statistics' sake when digivolving back and forth with your favourites).

The game runs superbly smooth. No matter how old your device is it will be able to play Time Stranger without fault.

**Reasons to Not Purchase Time Stranger**
------------------------------------------------
For the first third of the game, your team will be too weak to do much against bosses without heavy grinding. They will primarily be fought by guest characters, such as Aegiomon. This beginning all occurs in the human world, leaving the middle section split amongst the Digital World areas that feel underdeveloped as a result.

There is a randomized card battle minigame that provides absolutely no benefit or enjoyment despite there being dozens of NPCs programmed to play with you.

This game has plenty of DLC. In fact, the DLC menu here on Steam can easily be confused for a fighting game's. The detailed costumes and scenario missions were blatantly cut from the main game. There is also a season pass in the works that will include 5 DLC Digimon per season. The immediate DLC Digimon (Black & Friendship) can be unlocked ingame anyway, so don't bother buying them. Even alternative songs to the poor random encounter music cost money.

Denuvo has been installed into the core game files, meaning you cannot access your saves unless you remain connected to the internet. This program is also known to slightly slow down your computer, among other concerns such as privacy. Adding insult to injury, you cannot name your Digimon anything that could *possibly* be interpreted as inappropriate in English (despite this being a single-player game).

**Aspects to be Improved**
--------------------------------
Digimon evolutions (digivolutions) are limited to your avatar's level. If your favourite Digimon is a Mega (highest stage), then you must wait until the final third of the game to unlock it. I suppose this was to encourage players to play around with all 450+ Digimon included in Time Stranger, but
1) The previous entry, Cyber Sleuth, limited your party capacity depending on their stage. This was much fairer: you could get your favourite yet still be challenged by bosses.
2) Your Digimons' levels (1, 2, 3, ..... 99) play a greater role in their strength more than their statistics. A maximized level 20 Mega is much weaker than a level 40 Rookie. This is stellar if you do not wish to evolve your favourite Digimon, but a letdown for the impact of Digivolution presented in media.

The Digifarm does not allow you to Digivolve while you are logged into it, so you need to exit, open your Digivice, check if you meet the requirements to Digivolve, and then return to the farm if you do not. Combining both would greatly smooth out the evolution process.

Personalities are great because the Digimon will follow unique evolution paths and functions in your party. However, changing their personality is randomized by speaking to them. If there is a specific personality you want, you will need to train the farm, but won't have the money to quick train until the end of the game (negligible if you purchased the money outer dungeon).

For whatever reason, almost all of the side missions were reserved for just before the final battle. They're all quite fun and should have been accessible sooner.


**Verdict**
-------------
Time Stranger a high-quality 4-star game. Digimon fans old and new will have an excellent time with it. I recommend waiting for a sale to purchase the base game because it's truly worth ~$40 USD.
Here's to hoping Time Stranger's success will teach Konami to give future Digimon titles a budget larger than pocket change.

And honestly this game would have easily replaced it... If not for the story. I still love this game to bits and will absolutely finish it and still recommend it even after the story (at the moment) feels so badly written.

[h3]MASSIVE SPOILERS AHEAD!![/h3]

While I have yet to finish the game and a lot of my issues with the story might be answered then, there's one thing that I think would have made the story so much better: Remove the Agent, aka the Main Character, and their [spoiler]organisation ADAMS[/spoiler] from the story entirely.

This game CLEARLY actually wants [spoiler]Aegiomon[/spoiler] to be the main character and I'm left to wonder why that's not the case? What reason was there to not have the game have a [spoiler]Digimon[/spoiler] main character like the Shin Megami Tensei games? He's always in your party as a permanent guest character, you can even give him equipment and change his abilities.

Aside from that,[spoiler] your Operator and ADAMS as a whole being able to communicate with the MC in "real time" in another timeline as if their timeline is always parallel and moving in the same direction forward as the one (or the branch) the MC is in absolutely makes no sense.[/spoiler] There should be no way the MC could communicate with them, because otherwise the organisation would have access to communicating to [spoiler]multiple Agents at once.[/spoiler] If anything, the MC should only be able to communicate to [spoiler]ADAMS in the current time they're in[/spoiler], especially if every action, every change made via time travelling creates a new timeline; the "butterfly effect". Why not have the Operator be an AI guide instead? That way, it makes so much sense why they can communicate with the MC at all times and look into data they already have.
[spoiler]Dr. Yuki was erased, but his actions, ADAMS, and the memories of him still remain in the timeline the MC is from... That doesn't make any sense. The fact that the changes/interferences with the past affected the MC's original timeline can be clearly seen in the beginning of the game through the animation of the two agents with Aegiomon and Inori and "Aegiomon" interferring with the war just before the MC is sent to the past.[/spoiler]

Anyway, that's what I think about the story so far. If there's a huge "aha" moment and everything can be explained, i'll happily rethink and edit this review.

One last thing...
