Quite likely the best modern Digimon game. It solves pretty much all of the issues of Cyber Sleuth - and you're even able to change FMC's ugly default outfit almost right away! :D

On a more serious note, you can't help but love some of the improvements, such as proper difficulty levels (which you can switch on the fly - hell, you can pretty much switch everything on the fly, including the main character's gender/appearance). The grind is much less tedious, and you can alleviate it even more by training/feeding your Digimon on the farm, talking to them, and investing in your Agent's skill trees (side note: the human character being able to help during fights in more offensive ways than just chucking healing items at their 'mons is a super cool idea, and I hope they stick with it). Surprisingly, even the post-battle auto-heal feels more like the game valuing your time rather than like too much hand-holding.

The plot is far from being super deep, but it's serviceable. It even manages to feel like an anime series at times, what with there being some truly dramatic plot twists and sacrifices, some properly epic action sequences, some cutesy and/or silly moments, and even some vaguely Persona-like mysterious shenanigans.

The characters are quite likeable, though it would've been nice if there had been a couple more of them, at least of the major ones, and more opportunities to talk to them (this goes for your own Digimon, too; it would be nice to have at least one special 'mon with whom you could converse and/or a much bigger choice of random conversations with all of your 'mons).

The FMC/MMC is fine, though they barely have some personality and they are more of a spectator of Inori's/Aegiomon's story for big chunks of the game. I didn't mind it, I just wish my Agent had felt slightly more relevant to the story before the endgame. It also kinda sucks that the character you decide to play as isn't voiced at all, especially since your counterpart's voice lines as the operator are, as those of other characters, pretty nicely acted (at least in the Japanese version; no idea about the English voices, though the snippets that I've heard didn't sound supremely grating).

While I slightly miss the more cyberspace-like digital side of Cyber Sleuth's world, the Digimon world in this game is refreshingly vibrant (c'mon, tell me you weren't at least half as surprised and impressed as the characters upon visiting Central Town or Junomon's temple for the first time), and feels very much like a callback to the first and second Digimon series. The overall vibe of the game, however, is darker and more Tamers-like, which is a combo that I absolutely adore, seeing as Tamers will quite likely always be my favourite series, but I've always loved the feel of the digital world in the first series. Overall there's a decent amount of references and easter eggs from all corners of the franchise, from 'mon-/situation-exclusive dialogue lines to various iconic attacks being translated into the game's mechanics pretty well.

Getting back to the more technical side, the game is decently translated, and it sounds well (including some truly catchy tunes). It runs pretty smoothly except in some areas in which there's plenty of 'mons (this happens even on a decent setup). The quality of some textures is definitely on the lower side, but you can get used to it, considering the overall retro/cartoony vibe of the game's graphics.

Now here's some less awesome bits:

I do agree with one of the most popular reviews: all of this still doesn't mean that the gameplay is groundbreaking; it's just noticeably less frustrating than in most if not all previous entries. And, of course, there still are some issues, some of them pretty weird and outdated, such as the game still being written only with the MMC in mind (which results in some unintentional hilarity), or the game's gameplay time and achievement count going totally bonkers if you like to play offline (look, Steam Deck's battery isn't all that great). Fortunately, saves still get properly synchronized with the cloud. And speaking of saves and being outdated - limited save slots? And less than two dozen of them? Really?

There still are some supremely grindy bits, one of them being... the frustratingly random card mini-game (at least it's completely optional). And don't get me started on some Outer Dungeon challenges. The racing ones are more frustrating than any boss in the game.

Also, seeing as all of the game's versions are atrociously priced (I definitely wouldn't have been playing the game any time soon if I hadn't gotten it as a gift), some content STILL being locked behind separate DLCs even if you own the Ultimate edition is beyond shameless. No, I don't care that it's just a music bundle and some dungeons for grinding, it still means that Bandai/Namco is choosing to portray itself as the most stereotypical greedy corpo. Envious of Nintendo's infamy, huh?

Either way, here's some wishful thinking for the next game: unlimited or at the very least more save slots, less awkward treatment of the FMC, a fully voiced FMC/MMC (!!!), more polished and better explained training/talent/bond systems, less half-empty dungeons, more 'mons from recent anime series/movies, more dialogue lines for all of your 'mons and/or an option to have one special partner Digimon, more variety when it comes to offensive skill discs... More hi-res textures would be nice, too. Oh yeah, and no more extra-super-separate DLC bulls***t; let's not turn people off of a franchise that already isn't among the most popular ones, yeah?

TL;DR: Great game for diehard Digimon fans; will definitely be less enthralling for people who aren't very familiar with the Digimon 'verse and/or who prefer a more cartoony, Pok√©mon-like approach to their monster-catching games (which is completely fine, of course). Either way, it's a noticeable step forward for Digimon games.

Time Stranger is a peculiar game, and the exact kind of game I wish I could give a mixed review for.  Tl;drs for each part.

First, let's compare its gameplay to Digimon Cybersleuth, the most similar game to it.  Generally, the game is an improvement.  One of Cybersleuth's biggest flaws is def piercing attacks being so much better than everything else that they are essentially mandatory.  This is NOT present in this game, but Time Stranger brings a new flaw: boring unique attacks.  Almost all Unique Attacks from in-training to Ultimate digimon are dull.  Simple damage dealing attacks with few effects.  As an example, let's use Skullgreymon.  In Cybersleuth, Skullgreymon's Oblivion Bird has this effect "Physical attack, 110 Fire damage to one foe. 50% chance of reducing target's DEF by 10%."  Compared to Time Stranger's Skullgreymon, "Performs Fire physical attack at power 90."  Time Stranger's attack has a lot less going on, and this is case for almost all digimon below Mega.  Even Time Stranger's Mega digimon tend to have very similiar effects.  Most either ignore attributes or decrease the targets resistance or debuff or status effect enemies (there are a few more).
Tl;dr, more balanced than Cybersleuth but also more boring.

Time Stranger's biggest flaw is its story.  Its incoherent.  There's really not much to say about without spoilers, but it feels like the writer died multiple times and was replaced.  It jumps from wild idea to wild idea, including but not limited to: being a secret agent, being a dectective, being a time traveller, being a time traveller (again), etc.  The individual ideas work, and could be very interesting if explored in depth, but they just aren't.  Characters are treated very similiarly, not being given nearly enough time to explore them.  All of the characters are varying degrees of bland.

Despite all this, I enjoyed Time Stranger.  Training digimon is lots of fun, and there are a ton of cool and exciting digimon.  Most of them are even pretty effective, in their own ways.

Tl;dr; very flawed, still a fun digimon game.  I wish the story was less terrible, and that the price tag was more reasonable.  Pretty fun game, coulda been better.

negative.review:
I'm torn on this one. 
It's the best digimon ever made. It's higher effort than any pokemon game ever made. The story is great, the game is beautiful, the world feels alive. 

But it feels dirty. The monetization would make EA applaud. Day 1 outer dungeon DLC practically required for the higher difficulties. They shove DLC in multiple in-game menus. The post game is non-existent, and you're going to have to buy that separately as another DLC in January. 

So although the game itself deserves a thumbs up, I think the developer deserves a thumbs down for the way they're trying to milk their fans.

[h1]The Digimon Game that Made Me Give Up on Digimon Games.[/h1]

I've always struggled with sticking to modern Digimon games as they often are plagued with a slew of problems that they've latched onto for nostalgia-baiting purposes. Time Stranger steps away from that time honored tradition that Digimon Games follow and tries to set itself apart and cater to NEW players who might have an interest in the game. Unfortunately whilst Time Stranger sets itself apart from other Digimon games, the game just isn't particularly that great, and if you've played any generic turn-based RPG from the early 2000's or even now you've basically played it. Admittedly I've tried SO HARD to like this game as it does stand apart from other Digimon games, but the experience is either largely bland or bad for the majority of the game to the point that I can't bring myself to continue wasting time playing it.

Furthermore there seems to be this.. Overall consensus that a large portion of the community has regarding this game which is that "It gets good around the 25-30 hour mark", and admittedly I find that to be insanity. In our world where there's an ever-growing supply of games which can be FUN and ENGAGING from the first 5 minutes, why spend your time on something which isn't fantastic from the first step? Are the standards of people playing this game so astronomically low that they think this is ok? Even the #1 Review AT CURRENT says the game is essentially boring/mid yet rates it positively due to it being A DIGIMON GAME.

There's so many things in this game that make it obvious that the game is half-baked like there only being basically 5 voice actors for all the Digimon when they attack - I sincerely hope you like the voice of in-game Agumon because it's possible to have 15 different Digimon you use which have the same voice! Time Strangers' marketing paints the game as having these grandiose and beautiful overworld areas, but all these are is cleverly disguised hallways and linear paths. 

Time Strangers' gameplay is overall boring and so badly wants to be mechanically deep and interesting yet doesn't give you enough tools for that to be the case and restricts your actual usage of tactics. Gameplay for the game quickly devolves into "Does your Digimon have the type which is resistant to the enemy? No? Do you have Convert?". Almost every single attack in the game is basically just a reskin of every other single attack in the game, and bosses being resistant to most statuses means that the only real "tactical gameplay" to be had is just whether you debuff them or not. 

Time Strangers' view of difficulty seems to be confused for annoyance, with the bosses not even being hard to take on within the hard difficulty. Boss fight formula in this game is essentially the boss pulling some dumb bullshit out of nowhere repeatedly to *TRY* to make the fights require you to think, yet they still devolve into using three Digimon which are resistant to the boss and nothing more because you're not given any other options than to buff and sweep.

Time Strangers' story is extremely predictable and almost all of the characters just feel so unlikable within the storyline, with constant terrible and predictable choices plaguing the narrative to the point it feels like your stereotypical shonen anime. On top of this the progression system feels incredibly padded to make it to where you're FORCED to spend more time playing the game to Digivolve anything to a Digimon you might actually care about. Time Strangers' Agent Rank system is admittedly worse than the grinding system in CyberSleuth which already wasn't great. 

Go play something else which is fun from the start.

Game lacks any sort of complexity, and ends up being boring and repetitive after a couple of hours. Story and characters didn't do it for me either. The card game is horrible, nothing like losing every battle even though your cards are stronger and have type advantage because of the horrible randomness. 
The game is very linear and the way that Digimon ... work, just doesn't do it for me. It's grindy, simple, and really lacks any sense of advancement since most evolutions boil down to just increasing stats. The evolutions are also mandatory and not really ... difficult to get, so they don't really make sense to me (at least for as long as I played). The concept of course makes sense, but everything is so simple nothing feels rewarding. When I look at the evolution charts, I'm not even sure what ones are supposed to be difficult to get. Even the ones that need higher stats are just need to be put into training and leveled up, it's not like you need to do anything complicated. 
Thinking about it, I wasn't a real fan of the battle system to begin with. It starts out ok, but gets brain dead easy about 5 hours in. Typeing maters a lot, but nothing is really difficult enough for it to mater, so just spamming different elements until you find one that it's weak to doesn't feel rewarding and just ends up feeling like a chore.
I wouldn't really consider it a bad game, but I can't recommend it due to the oversimplification and lack of variety of things to do.

For reference, I'm an RPG veteran and love the Digimon franchise. I wish there was a middle-grade rate that I could give this game, but due to the nature of game mechanics and just video games in general, I elected to veer on the side of negative. That said, let's get into it.

I am actually very disappointed. I went into this extremely optimistic. I'm currently going through the Cyber Sleuth games and having a wonderful time with them. I think the presentation and story of Time Stranger is very appealing, and it hooked me in effortlessly. There was clearly a lot of love put into it.

So what's the issue?

Difficulty. Now, I understand that this is a very volatile discussion for everyone, and I'm not here to tell anyone how to enjoy the game. If you're having a good time with it, great. All the more power to you. However, I have to point out that what separates a game from other pieces of media is the ability to interact with it. If a game demands practically nothing from me, then my brain checks out, and if my brain checks out, I'm not playing anymore, now am I? The game is playing itself. I'm just the guy in the chair, tilting a stick and occasionally pressing a button.

The reason this is important is because I selected hard difficulty with the expectation that I would be challenged. I expected, reasonably, that the developers had designed the game in such a way that I could interact with all of its mechanics and still find portions of it difficult. That is what the word, "hard," is meant to imply in this context.

But nearly fifteen hours into the game, and not a single encounter has challenged me. Seeing how easy every encounter has been up until now, I turned on autobattle, and I was mortified to find that my team was cleaning through encounters like nobody's business. To make matters worse, you can hold still and wait for your digimon to fully recover. So, there's nothing stopping you from keeping autobattle on 24/7 and just moving from encounter to encounter. No resource management or tactics required. Just sit back and let the game play itself.

I've heard the argument, "Well just don't use autobattle," or "Wait until mega+," or "then don't use the mechanics."

Autobattle shouldn't be here to begin with. To me, that demonstrates a lack of confidence in the player.

Asking me to play the game for 50+ hours for a new difficulty is absurd.

Lastly, going back to what I said before, what separates a game from other forms of media is its ability to be interacted with. If I'm just on autobattle the whole time, moving from marker to marker, and am not required to put any real thought into my setup or my evolutions beyond the rock-paper-scissors format of combat, then I fall asleep at the wheel.

I'm not asking for it to break the average player's back, but Cyber Sleuth has consistently challenged me in areas. Other JRPGs, such as Etrian Odyssey, Persona, any game in the Shin Megami Tensei series, and fights from the original Final Fantasy and Dragon Quest games gave me the occasional run for my money. But there's nothing like that here, and judging from what I've read online, it doesn't get any harder. Only easier.

Can I really still call this a game? This is more of an interactive novel.

Thank you for reading. And please, if you're enjoying it, do not let me opinion sour your mood. It's still leagues better than Pokemon ZA.

[b][u]An extremely greedy corporation with no shame[/u][/b], unfortunately forcing it on a niche franchise like Digimon

You hardly have any customisation at all (only meh shirts) aside 4 cosmetic DLCs for 5-7 bucks each.

[u]TL;DR[/u] [i][b]The game is good but I gave it a negative review because I don't want BANDAI to keep going toward that greedy direction[/b][/i]

- What i wanted: A digimon creature capture game, where i could hunt and train my digimons.
- What i got: A story focused game with small, linear maps, which feels like a visual novel at mid game (story > move to point x, can ignore enemies, as strong enough > beat a boss > more story).

This game could be good, but it has big problems:
Lack of gameplay:
- evolutions gated behind story progress: feels like you need to rush story, if you want to play "monster tamer" style
- (boring and) slow story pacing: game is focused on story, so a lot of cutscenes will "slow" you down, till you hit max evolution level
- from a certain point onwards, no new features will be introduced for a long time (you won't need new Digimon anymore, as the existing ones should be strong enough; you'll then play for several more hours to reach the next evolution) -> what remains is a story that drags on
- sidequest are not optional: it tells, that you can do them later, but you will miss out exp point for "your personal level", which means you will unlock higher evolution much later -> the slow story pacing gets slower
- later quests and sidequest involve a lot of backtracking -> another thing that makes progression slower
- maps are small, linear and have often small "cutscene" features like climbing a ladder. Furthermore there is a 1 - 2 second loading screen between two map sections -> gets annoying, as small map sections = a lot of loading times 
- digifarm? can be ignored, as it is just a boring "grid"

Generic Story:
Write a generic story and replace people with digimon...and you have some Chapters for your game.

Price and dlc:
And then there is the high price and you dont get everything in the base game, as there a lot of dlcs (mostly cosmetic and music, bust still...).

To summarize: The game is heavy story focused with a slow pacing. At some point it lacks of introducing new systems to keep the game interesting. The map and mission designe is very bad, because it is too heavily based on old systems, that were designed that way in the past due to hardware limitations.

:Spoiler:
The most anoying part about it was that even after beating the game, you cant go back and do the stuff you missed, if you wanna do it again, you have to do NG+ or start a completly new save, there is no inbetween. which me and ALOT of other fans are really annoyed about, that it states there is "endgame content" but that so called "endgame content" is just NG+, which isnt always what we want in a Digimon game. this is probably the only time ill tell Digimon to actually do a "pokemon" and do proper endgame content instead of just a NG+ that they are so "good" at.
:Spoiler end:

All in all, its not a bad game, sadly i cannot rectify the 70 Euro pricetag, the game just.. does NOT have that kind of Quallity or Quantity if gameplay, it doesnt even have 300 digimon in it, which is actually a really sad part. as thats also one of the reasons ive stopped playing Pokemon, just a MASSIVE roster, but never uses it. with a Roster of OVER 1500 DIGIMON, id atleast expect 500, but only around 250? thats just not worth it then.
gameplay is also not good enough for 70 Euro at all, i was considdering getting the Ultimate Edition and was sorrely dissapointed in it when i saw you dont even get all the DLC or addons... FOR 120 EURO?!?!

The gameplay is a solid turn based monster battler and trainer, but the writing is some of the worst out there and they didn't even finish the voice acting for the game. Some random side quests will have it but then the MSQ won't. At this price point PLUS microtransactions on release it's crazy to not finish voicing the game. The silent digivolving and attacks are also kinda lame, maybe it's for the best since some of the voices are like nails on a chalkboard (both english and japanese). The silent main character stuff also needs to stop. if you don't know how to do it well, then don't do it. I get it 'bUt PoKeMon DoEs It'. don't be pokemon, be digimon. Also, gating your power progression with bland side quests is one of the worst game design choices i have ever seen. Forget to do 1 side quest and you are gated on power for literal hours until you prog the msq enough, and by then you get just get inundated with mundane fetch quests with massive amounts of meaningless dialog. There is such little gameplay doing the side quests (that you have to do because of agent points) that i see why they added the microtransaction dungeons. The game is designed in a way to make you want to buy them because the base game reward structure and progression is just that bad. The more i trudge through the tedium of mandatory boring walking simulator sidequests, the more i grow to hate this game.

This game might have the biggest dropoff in quality and interest I've felt in YEARS.
The intro/prologue do a wonderful job of pulling you in and promising a ton with regards to both gameplay and story, and then those hooks fade away in favor of the most rote, monster-of-the-week plot possible tied to an extremely barebones gameplay system that doesn't evolve in the slightest past that intro.
The only worthwhile part of this game is the designs of the Digimon themselves, but because everything can learn a good-enough version of every skill in the game, and because everything can have any stats with the right time/money/item investment, they're all basically just skins over a single party member copy-pasted hundreds of times.
Don't waste your time, or if you feel you must then be sure to get the game on a STEEP discount, because $70 is basically highway robbery for how incredibly dull this game is past hour 2.

I enjoy the game and it improves a lot upon the prior Digimon Story games. However, I can not recommend the game at this time because of game breaking bugs. I was very excited for this release and was avoiding all spoilers, but in doing this, I missed discussions about bugs. I only have one save file because I'm a fool. I'm not going to restart the game and I'm waiting for the next patch. I'll update my review at that time but right now, I'm upset that I can't continue on my save.

I have no experience with Digimon so I was sold by the high praise this game was receiving. I can see what is endearing and if you are into monster collecting, this feels like an IP that actually made an effort and appreciates it fans. 

However I got this for turn-based combat and team building, neither of which it excels at compared to competitors. Digimon themselves are not unique apart from visuals, the vast majority only have 1 unique move which is usually just a damage dealing move. Personality and skills can be changed as well, so the is no inherent uniqueness to each stage of your Digimon apart from elemental weakness/strength. Digimon appeal is very much vibes based on designs you think are cool as they all function the same.

Since the monster trainer game aspect feels shallow to me, the rest of the package eventually burnt me out. It's not bad, it just fine, but that probably isn't worth the price tag or time investment to non-Digimon fans.

Now that would've been something! So hear me out, wait for a sale and get this title if you REALLY think you need it - the nostalgia just didn't hit me with that one.

I have a lot of thougths and feeling about this game so allow me to summarize them:

Creature Collectors are among my favourit genre of videogame, so whenever a new one releases, I am obviously curious and since this one got pretty good reviews(at the time of me writing this) I wanted to check it out and let me preface the rest of this wall of text by saying that I don't activly hate the game. It does get one thing very rigth, and that is the dopamine hit of getting and evolving new creatures. I do enjoy that nothing has a linear evolution-path. Sadly enough, that is the most positive thing I can say about the game.

The story itself is... mediocre. I do not wish to spoil it for anyone, so I will deliberatly keep it vague and it had me hooked at times, but after seeing it in it's entirety it left me wanting. There was potential there, but it got squandered by clichees, plottpoints that get picked up and just fade into nothingness, storybeats that drag on far too long and the good old forced twists and turns many rpgs suffer from where they try to get as many shocking reveals in as possible that ultimately turn the story into nonsense the second u sit down and look at it in it's plotthole-riddled entirety. All of those though, are the smaller issues the story is suffering from, the far bigger one is the moment to moment storytelling, the actual character-dialogue. Characters repeat what they just said over and over, I wish I was exxegerating, but I constantly had characters repeat what they said 1-2 sentences ago in the same conversation UP TO FOUR TIMES. It's honestly insane and if you played a well written RPG over the last few months the tonal whiplash will definitly get you.

The biggest issue though, is the combat. There are some nice quality of life things here, like the ability to just speed up mid combat via flicking the rigth stick, or even turn on auto-combat when u just have to figth through random mobs. But there is also most of the bossfigths beeing far to tanky, so that u know u r definitly gonna beat them by repeating the same inputs u did for the last 5 minutes for 10 more minutes(there were 2 bossfigths that took me over an hour, even though I had the game running at 5x speed and that was with maxed out digimon, after completing all the sidequests AND having elemental advantages). There is also the rockpaperscissor type combat system, which in of itself isnt an issue but how it is used. The vast majority of bossfigths are virus-type digimon, so data and virus type digimon are kinda useless. I was literally using the same all-vaccine-type-team for the last 9 bossfigths straigth, no clever composition, no tactics, just the same type of typeadvantages that worked consistently. It's not even like there is a plot-reason why they couldnt use more data or vaccine type digimons as bossfigths, that those dont work as a strict allignement-chart has been established time and time again.

All of these things make this an experience I can't really recommend in good faith, at least not at full price(someone called this an AA game that got priced as AAA and its kinda fitting). It will give u the dopamine from constantly getting new creatures, which is just a winning formular and why I love this genre so much, but you can get interesting new creatures in other games with better mechanics, writing and pricing and without BS MTX that pester u at several ingame-stores.
if you just want to raise digimon, there is way to much friction and gate keeping from the story to have fun raising mons

Wanna be clear, I 100% this game in 50 hours, (100% meaning all side-missions, beating the main story, and completing the digimon-pokedex) That's fairly depressing for a $70 rpg.

Decided to pick this up over Pokemon, as the quality of the pkm series continues to drop I figured Digimon would be better, however this game's quality is just as poor as any modern Pokemon game. I have to imagine most people who are recommending this game is just used to the series being bad, but since I was expecting an actual good game I was caught off-guard.

The Pros:
-The Digimon look very nice. Good animations all round, and there are cool stuff like being able to ride certain Digimon, and seemingly every digimon has it's own unique "battle victory" animation.

-Uhhh you can skip cutscenes I guess?

The Cons:
-Everything else in the game

-Gameplay is horribly boring, and they KNOW this is the case because you can speed the animations up to 5x, with an auto-battle so you don't have to actually do anything either. I have to admit, at least they make skipping things very streamline, but grinding is just soulless.

-Permanent stats are poorly explained, even now I don't really understand how they work. Not to mention dealing with personalities is just awful, getting them to move in the correct direction without using the farm training (i.e. waiting 15 irl minutes multiple times) is basically impossible. Your best bet is just ignoring them completely until your far enough in the game to just quick-complete farm training and deal with them like that.

-Additionally, the game is extremely easy, even on hard. This is double annoying, as they have difficulty settings, and even allow you to lower/raise them at any time. It's just rock-paper-scissors, only you can swap out your team at any time for free. It's pokemon, but you can change pokemon and still attack. Plus, you can farm infinite stats. I was playing the entire game trying to complete the digi-dex, so my main team wasn't even max leveled or trained much or anything, so the game could have been even easier.

-The story seems cool in theory, but the characters and cutscenes are so bad it doesn't matter. Everytime I have to choose 1 of 3 of the same dialogue option but slightly different I get so annoyed I skip the rest. I think alot of the larger ideas / themes of the story are super cool, but so much of what you actually engage with is "wow a bad thing is happening, lets go stop the bad thing" with 0 depth and nothing interesting going on. Idk, maybe I'm expecting too much? It's very hard to watch these cutscenes compared to something like the xenoblade series, at least to me. They also do a TON of exposition dumping, which I consider a red flag that usually showcases a failure of storytelling.

-Absolutely no polish. There are so many small things wrong with this game it's crazy. The most annoying is lack of menu optimization. the menu to evolve your Digimon is different from the one to move your party, which is different from the one to level enhance. This gets compounded when you need to train on the digi-farm. Let's say you need +300 ATK to digivolve your mon, so you put it into the farm to train ATK. You can no longer access the digivolve menu. This means you need to know when you have enough ATK, or else you have to take it out of the farm, check again, then put it back. That doesn't sound too bad, until you realize you have 6 party members, and a ton of extra digimon you may be trying to evolve at any 1 time. You might have 1 digimon that needs 300 ATK, 1 that needs 200 DEF, 1 that need 400 SPI, and 1 that need to change it's personality. Good luck keeping track of all that.

All in all, this is a $30 game that could have been sold for $40 because Digimon, but is instead $70 because they can I guess. A complete joke for the price. Similar to pokemon, unless your a die-hard fan, it's not worth it at all. Very disappointing.

So i bought this game after reading reviews, watching some gameplay and cutscenes, and checking out how many Digimon are in the game. If you're enjoying this game, that's great. It's better than what Gamefreak is pushing out.

Let's get some positives out of the way first:
- There is indeed a lot of Digimon. Even though many are very similar to each other, i have no complaints there.
- Animations for most of the moves are solid.

Now, the negatives obviously outweigh the positives since i do not recommend this game.
- Combat pretty much plays itself. Just spam attack. There's no real gameplay here. Especially since i picked the harder difficulty, expecting to actually use my brain to beat encounters. There was one battle that i lost, and only won because i was lucky. One battle in 7.5 hours that i somewhat enjoyed. Combine this with how many encounters are spammed around in some areas and for me it's a repetitive recipe for disaster. This is by far my biggest complaint.

- Story is okay. It's not bad, but it's not great either. If the gameplay wouldn't be so stale, this wouldn't have bothered me as much. Since it's a Digimon game, i wasn't expecting much to begin with. But i had to try and find some redeeming qualities that could keep me playing. The story fails to deliver in that regard. 

- The biggest portion of the game i was sent down into sewers and empty buildings. Cool. In the trailer there's these cool looking areas and so far i've only seen the Digimon city, which was fun, but guess what? I was sent into the sewers there too! Why? 

It starts off with a bang and it was definitely fun at first. But it's all downhill from there. Result is that i can't refund it. So i feel tricked in a way for sure.

This game really just feels like Pok√©mon‚Äôs awkward knockoff cousin. Every Digimon looks like someone mashed up a Pok√©mon with a microwave and said ‚Äúyeah that‚Äôs fine.‚Äù Half of them look like they belong in a recycling bin, not a battle.

The story keeps shouting ‚ÄúDIGITAL WORLD!!!‚Äù like it‚Äôs supposed to impress me, but it honestly just made me wish I was playing literally any Pok√©mon game instead. At least Pok√©mon evolutions actually make sense and don‚Äôt turn your cute starter into a metal dinosaur printer or whatever.

Combat is basically Pok√©mon if everything had too many buttons and yelled at you constantly. Digimon fans keep saying it‚Äôs ‚Äúdeeper,‚Äù but I think that‚Äôs just because you need a wiki open 24/7 to understand anything.

I find this game deeply flawed. 

It's meant to be a very story heavy game, but the story is just not satisfying nor coherent. Also has a lot of repetition. Characters are introduced in a very dry manner, you get a short amount of time with them, they go away for extremely long time & then you revisit them and the game acts like they're important characters. There's a dozen+ of these characters which all follow this same pattern. There are plot twists, but you usually see them coming miles off or they're just underwhelming or complete nonsense. 

Digivolving digimon is a big part of my enjoyment in digimon games, yet in this one it feels unnecessary to really do a lot of this. Most of the game you'll be stuck with Ultimate rank digimon as the jump to mega takes forever. You can't chart out digivolution paths ingame (even using online sites its a big chore) leading to it being a very annoying chore. The way stats stay and grow is very unclear as well.

The personality system is just boring, you talk to your digimon & can nudge them in a personality direction. sometimes you get 4 options, sometimes 1. it feels cheap, doesnt feel rewarding. You can also move personality on the digi farm, which is even more of a chore & takes 10 minutes of real life time (or payment of ingame money)

The world itself is also kind of just really uninteresting. The maps have some exploration, but its usually just "take dead end side path, get an item you already have 20 of". Don't expect to have to solve puzzles, or fight optional bosses to open new areas. Its always just corridors with some short side paths. 

Fights themselves are very very easy except for boss fights, which are basically HP sponge fights even when using hits at 300%. Combined with scripted HP% activated "boss does big move hit a spot to cancel" mechanics. 

Now grinding to gain exp, and digivolve to the digimon you want is a big aspect of the game (though largely optional), but the game just doesnt really let you grind anywhere in a satisfying manner. enemy density is low, the corridors have constant "gaps" where you gotta go through a dialogue option to appear on the other side. Digimon dont reappear except when you reenter areas either so its just extremely tedious and boring if you actually want to digivolve a lot of digimon for completion sake. Ofc they do sell a 7‚Ç¨ DLC that lets you grind EXP items extremely easily. Which is just scummy. Endgame supposedly does have better grinding spots, but like that's a really long slog to get to.

I just don't get who the target audience is for this game. If you want a good story, this aint it. If you want good gameplay, this aint it. If you want to grind & digivolve a lot of digimon, this aint it. 

Tl:DR 5/10 game.

A great game ruined by a corrupted save. This review is mainly a warning about a potential issue playing exclusively on the steam deck.

Throughout my nearly 30 hours of playing my save data was corrupted 4 different times. Each time it happened I was manually saving and in the middle of that, the steam deck crashed and reset itself. When I tried loading the game it said the data was corrupted. The first 3 times I was able to verify game files, and attempt to load the auto save data and save to a new slot. This worked. The 4th time however, following the same steps, when I launched the game it automatically started new game. It didn't even launch to the home screen of the game, it put me directly into a new game where it told me to select a difficulty. No matter what I did this was the outcome. I created a new game, waited for the unskippable intro then attempted to load my save data again only to see it was completely wiped and replaced with 00:00 playtime data. It would refuse to load and any autosave data was replaced when starting the new game. This is a very rare bug that can happen but considering the frequency of which this was happening while exclusively on the steam deck is something worth warning people of.

[h1]Wish I Could Leave a ‚ÄúMixed‚Äù Review, Because That‚Äôs Exactly How I Feel[/h1]

I really wish Steam had an official ‚Äúmixed‚Äù rating option, because Digimon Story: Time Stranger lands squarely in that middle ground for me. I was a big Digimon fan back in the PS1 days, but I fell off the series after that. When I heard this new entry was a turn-based RPG and people were calling it better than the modern Pok√©mon games, I figured it was finally time to jump back in.

And to be fair, the combat is genuinely fun and interesting. The turn-based system has depth, experimenting with different Digimon is enjoyable, and there‚Äôs a nice variety of team setups to play around with. Battles were easily the highlight of the experience for me, and I can definitely see why long-time fans love the monster-collecting side of things.

But unfortunately‚Ä¶ the story lost me fast. It‚Äôs extremely anime, but not the good kind of anime. The pacing, the dialogue, the tone, it just didn‚Äôt hook me at all. I found myself zoning out during cutscenes and waiting to get back to the battles instead. Compared to modern Pok√©mon games, which at least give you things like online battles or Raid Battles to break up the monotony, Time Stranger feels more restrictive. If the story bores you, there isn‚Äôt much else to fall back on.

Overall, I‚Äôm left with mixed feelings. The combat is fun, there‚Äôs a huge roster of Digimon to experiment with, and mechanically it‚Äôs solid. But the story, unfortunately a major part of the game, is a real let down for me. Fans who love Digimon narratives might feel differently, but if you‚Äôre here for gameplay and a strong story matters to you, temper your expectations.

I am very conflicted about this game even though I had quite a lot of fun with it. If I had the option to give it a neutral review, I would have chosen that.

For starters, the pricing policy of Bandai Namco is indefensible in my opinion. While Digimon Story Time Stranger certainly has the highest production value of any game in the franchise, it still is a AA game that somehow asks for 120‚Ç¨ for its ‚Äûultimate edition‚Äú to get the full content. For reference, this is more than Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3 and Clair Obscur‚Äôs day one prices combined and that is kind of ridiculous. It is also more than what Final Fantasy VII Rebirth asked for. Not only is the production quality of all aforementioned games (significantly) better, none of them sell predatory day one ‚ÄûEXP for money‚Äú DLCs like Digimon Story unfortunately does. Yes, you wont‚Äôt need that DLC, but that‚Äôs beyond the point. With this pricing the game puts itself far above any of the best RPGs of the recent 2-3 years while not being able to see eye to eye with them in most aspects. I‚Äôm sorry, but that alone already warrants a negative review.

Now you might argue that the pricing shouldn‚Äôt matter in a review, and that you are rather interested in knowing whether this game is good or not. What you are willing to pay for it is your business alone. Fair enough I guess.

[h3] Things to be enthusiastic about [/h3]
The game has a lot of positive surprises in it. The story may start slowly, but after the first third of its runtime the tension and mystery picks up a lot. It is genuinely a gripping and emotional story with a great main cast and some very positive side characters. Some twists you‚Äôll probably see coming but others will catch you by surprise. Be prepared for the story to feature mature and fairly dark themes such as war and how it affects the population of humans and digimon alike. Don‚Äôt worry though, it manages that without feeling overly oppressive or depressive. 

Every digimon has a unique special attack animation, sometimes even more than one which is awesome. And there are all these little details on top of that, which show how much love has been put into this game. For instance every time you use an item in fight on one of your digimon, they happily emote to that. It is really cute and a nice touch. Speaking of the battle system, it has a lot of (semi-deep) tactical options and things you‚Äôll need to manage. The latter boss fights are a delight and you have some great challenges as end-game-content.

[h3] Things that are good and bad at the same time [/h3]
The game has some rather mixed choices in its game design and narration. While the story does get much better later on, the first 20-25 hours are uneventful and at times even somewhat painful to get through. It doesn‚Äôt help that most of the human characters are kinda one-dimensional and not all that interesting unlike the great digimon cast for both friends and foes alike. That is a bit of a pity.

Similarly, the battles are great and disappointing at the same time. Yes, I mentioned fun boss fights and I really did like them. Well, mostly the second half of them because the first were almost trivial despite choosing the ‚Äûhard‚Äú difficulty. However, the real issue are the mob battles. With one exception none of the regular fights were challenging at all. They felt like copy paste filler in between boss fights, which is a shame considering that this is what you‚Äôll do the majority of the game. I acknowledge that this is sadly quite prevalent especially in RPGs. Games like Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3 and Clair Obscur showed that this doesn‚Äôt need to be the case though.

[h3] The game‚Äôs serious flaw [/h3]
If you want to pinpoint the biggest issue of the game with a bit of an edgy comment, it would look something like this: ‚ÄûYou‚Äôve most likely already played this game even if you‚Äôve never spend a single minute in it.‚Äú What do I mean with that? This is referencing the real antagonist of Digimon Story Time Stranger: the game and level design. 

If you have played any of the two Cyber Sleuth games, then you‚Äôve basically played this game with less quality-of-life features. In fact, this is also true if you‚Äôve played any linear turn-based RPG from the PS2 era onwards. You have small linear maps with copy paste mob enemies and (very short) loading screens when you move to the next location and of course also a fine selection of fetch-side-quests (go from a to b and fight c) over and over again‚Ä¶ Some call this ‚Äûnot pushing the boundaries of the genre‚Äú, others will see this as yet another attempt at the classical but overdone turn based RPG-formula with basically zero innovation. 

If that doesn‚Äôt bother you and if you really like turn based RPGs, then you probably will have a good, perhaps even great time with the game. If you‚Äôre looking for something fresh and unique, you‚Äôll find next to nothing here.

[h3] Conclusion [/h3]
Overall I did have fun with Digimon Story Time Strange and it does have some undeniable strengths. However, it is also very formulaic with a heavily dated map and quest design. You‚Äôll have to decide whether that is a deal-breaker to you or not.

Edit: I want to be absolutely clear: I'm not hating on the game. I'm not that far but I enjoy it. I simply hate the practice that Bandai Namco and other large publishers have of removing content and selling that content as an overpriced version or more DLC. It preys on people who have OCD or heaven forbid want a complete game. If missing content doesn't bother you, buy the standard edition. I simply do not recommend the "complete" game a the price it is currently. It's a good game from what I can tell so far, but you can get a LOT of good games for that price. If money doesn't matter to you then obviously this whole conversation doesn't. 

For people wondering why I bought it, this was a rare occasion. Most of my games are free or are gifted to me. When a company or series has a consistent record of $800 of DLC like modern Monster Hunter games, I avoid it. I get that a lot of you have enjoyed the game so far like myself. I'm certainly not trying to dampen that or offend you. I'm simply saying that I do not recommend a purchase at this time for people wanting the Ultimate Edition. Have a good one!

100% completion edit: Firstly, ignore the playtime. There's an AFK spot in the game to grind out levels for getting all the digivolutions. I did everything there was to do in the game. All digimon, all chests, perfect completions of all outer dungeons, etc. I enjoyed the game but I once again say wait for a sale. I enjoyed seeing the digimon, battling, and exploring when the game allowed me. I didn't enjoy the minor bugs like the digi-attack just not responding occasionally, the general extreme linearity, and the pacing of the game (the game dumps half the sidequests on you only after reaching the last story bit, for example). Speaking of sidequests, the translation effort/budget definitely didn't go into those. In particular, the second half or so of the sidequests had a ton of errors (wrong names showing up when clearly another character is talking happened more than once, for example). Overall I liked the game but the price to enjoyment ratio was a big miss.

Playing this game left me genuinely sad and mad. I‚Äôve been a Digimon fan for years, and after really enjoying Cyber Sleuth, I was genuinely excited for this one. I wanted to love it so badly, but couldn't.

It‚Äôs not just the game that frustrates me ‚Äî it‚Äôs the company behind it, and the players who keep enabling this nonsense. Watching people throw money at this just because it's a Digimon game feels pathetic. Nostalgia shouldn‚Äôt make you a paypig for a corporation that clearly doesn‚Äôt respect its fans.

This is a $70 title that barely lasts 35 hours, it‚Äôs impossible to recommend. Especially when other modern JRPGs like Persona or Expedition 33 offer more content, better pacing, and actual value for your money.

[h2]The Good[/h2]

‚úÖ The story is good, and the twist lands greatly (even if predictable).
‚úÖ The characters carry the game; you‚Äôll actually care for them, which is rare in monster-taming games. 
‚úÖ The core combat / Digimon evolution stuff is fun. There is a satisfaction in juggling builds and a wide variety of mons, but it really never challenges you meaningfully.
‚úÖ It‚Äôs enjoyable until the flaws nag at you so badly you want to quit.

[h3]The Bad[/h3]

‚ùåEvery side quest is ‚Äúgo to X, fetch Y, return,‚Äù over and over. No variation. Fifty fetch quests just to kill time.
‚ùåThere‚Äôs no good spot in the game where you can reliably grind or level up without frustration (unless you buy the grind DLC). And right before the final fight, they dump dozens of side-quests into your journal just so they can say they have content.
‚ùåAt launch, there were game-breaking bugs: like Aegiomon not recovering HP/SP outside of battles, the Pegasusmon egg bug, etc. Seems like they were too busy making a dozen DLCs to QA.

[h3]The Ugly[/h3]

‚ùå The game shipped with [b]TEN[/b] DLCs from day one. So the devs literally withheld content for extra cash.
‚ùå The season pass (at ~$30) gives you virtually nothing meaningful at launch. The big ‚ÄúGold Statue‚Äù is purely decorative. The rest (~15 ‚Äúmega digis‚Äù) are scheduled for rollout in 2026. You‚Äôre paying now for content you might not get (or may not be worth it) later.
‚ùå There is no multiplayer (no co-op, no trades, nothing). Previous Digimon Story titles allowed more social interactions; this one is utterly single-player.
‚ùå There‚Äôs an NPC whose sole function is to open the Steam store. The main menu has a button that opens the DLC store. The game feels like a giant ad.
But it's worse: [b]even if you don‚Äôt own a DLC item (outfit, music, whatever), the game adds it to your inventory menu anyway[/b]. If you accidentally click it, it pulls up the Steam store‚Äîunwanted prompts to buy garbage you didn‚Äôt ask for. 
‚ùå 20 bucks for a music DLC, lol.

[h3]Overall Take[/h3]
If you want to enjoy this, you‚Äôll have to mentally ignore the DLC crap, the side quests, the pacing issues, and the bugs. If you can do that, there‚Äôs a pulse of a decent JRPG underneath. But for what it charges, it fails to deliver.

If you like Digimon lore and are willing to be nickel-and-dimed, you might still find some joy. But if you expect a polished, generous JRPG you‚Äôll be disappointed.

As a casual Digimon fan, I REALLY want to like this game but the $70 price point is really killing this for me. The music is uninspiring, the animations are so-so, and the story+dialogue is sub-par. The only thing that is masking the stench is the joy of unlocking new Digimon. Just to preface, I am Agent level 6 at them moment to give an idea of where im at in the game. I have done all the side quests up to this point for reference. 

I'm sure that hardcore fans are loving this and that is good for them but as a general JRPG, its just okay. There are so many QoL features that are missing like getting to see the Digivolution lines in the farm. Why do I need to constantly open the farm in a non-tp-able area and swap between menus just to see what personality/stats I need to digivolve? It is just so convoluted.  

To no ones surprise, the game involves time travel. Time travel as the focal point of any story is a very delicate balancing act that needs to be done right. It is so easy to mess up a story that involves time travel. So what happens when you get a time travel story and bad dialogue? You get Time Strangers. The Operator is so unbelievably bad that it tears down a lot of my enjoyment of the game. They constantly (and I mean CONSTANTLY) bring up the most obvious things and regurgitates the same info they said 5 lines ago. Early in the game, the player finds out that their adoptive parent is dead/missing through dialogue between the Operator. Well, 40 hours in and they STILL mention it to like its the first time all while in the first few hours of the game they apologize for bringing up the topic and promising that they wont do it again. It's just exhausting seeing the player's phone ring and its the Operator just spewing the same garbage they did 2 minutes ago. ACTUAL DIALOGUE BTW; "I bet you remember your own adoptive father's mysterious appearance" and the context of this is... entering a new biome... 20ish hours into the game...

The music... I dont know man, there is just nothing that pops out to me. It just feels like generic JRPG music you can find anywhere. Nothing feels stylized or unique to the franchise, In the demo, there is a section of the game that has a 15+ second long sequence of where it sounds like a jet engine is about to explode. This LOOPS CONSTANTLY and the fix i found was changing the music. Such a shame.

You'll see such high praise for this game but it will mostly be from long time fans. As a Digimon game, it is pretty good, great even. As a videogame, it is sub-par and not worth the price tag. I love Digimon and the games, especially the older PSX titles. Unfortunately I feel disappointed in this one as it is yet another victim of the shittified modern industry. Luckily I was able to play it thanks to the Family Share. If I paid for this game I'd be very salty.

Positives:

- Pretty Graphics. The world really looks good, so do the Digimon and the animations. I never grew tired of them. 

- Good voice-acting. Played with JP voices and ENG subs. I find that the voices were fitting very well and sounded good.

- Interesting Story. In-line with what you'd expect from Digimon themed story but it was nice and I enjoyed reading it. If I ever play it again I probably won't be skipping it all either.

Negatives:

 - The game is ridiculously easy. It doesn't let you play the Mega or Mega+ mode on your 1st playthrough, you can only pick Hard. This is piss easy. You can auto-battle through most of the game, including side-quest bosses. Only some main story bosses require you to actually manually input your controls and they are still easy. The hardest side bosses/post-story bosses which are harder than the main story bosses on this difficulty require very little effort too. All you have to do is go face and spam items. No tactics or variety needed. I would like to point out I didn't do any grinding either. Just went forward and battled Digimon that were in my way.
If you're asking for specific points why it's too easy here you go:
        1. You automatically heal by standing still, this completely eliminates any sort of danger or need to be prepared. You never need items while just going around. Every battle is from full HP/SP, no risk of dying. In all previous games you'd only heal at specific spots or maybe before major encounters.
        2. You can freely swap Digimon during your turn as many times as you want before attacking. This used to consume your turn. 
        3. You can always use 1 item for free, even when swapping Digimon. This again used to consume your turn too. Now you can do both for free. It's not like the items are expensive or rare either. You get tons of money and items.
        4. Agent Skills are very OP. Both the X-Arts do ridiculous amount of work for you and the special nature skills let you evolve your Digimons too easily. This is a problem if you focus on one of the natures, you can easily get super strong Digimon through Digivolution and farm bonuses with no effort even unintentionally. 
        5. 3v3 Battles. Except not really, for almost the entire game it's at least 4v3 or even 6v3. You get an extra party member that's nearly always there whom you can customize with skills and items. This gives you drastic advantage as the member is actually good.  Not to mention there tend to be other guest members that will help you further, even if they aren't good at times they can still tank hits and seem to have at times unlimited HP.
        6. Digimon in Box get XP. You'd think this is to make sure you don't have to grind for all other Digimon, while that's true it's also a problem. In other games only Digimon in your party get XP. Here you have seemingly unlimited box size. Why is that bad? Well, whenever you convert a Digimon you can leave it in the box until it's max level or whenever you need them. As soon as you get a Digimon to evolve you just feed them all these useless Digimon to get tons of XP. So tl;dr this just gives you countless XP batteries for free.

You'd think that these may've been decisions to improve the QoL for people who aren't used to grinding or don't have too much time. I'd be willing to concede that point but then you have to compensate for it in other ways otherwise things just become boring. This games gives you everything, all the time. At least on the hardest difficulty that you can pick during your 1st playtrough. 
While I understand you can make the game harder for yourself by imposing your own rules I don't find that as valid argument. It's developer's job to provide adequate challenge, especially when the game has multiple modes. What is ''Hard'' here I'd normally consider ''Easy'' difficulty. In no world should you wait until NG+ to actually be challenged. I may try it if enough new content/mods are released for the game and update the review then.

- Not that many new/different Digimon compared to previous titles. If we're talking Cyber Sleuth/Hacker's Memory or even Next Generation I feel like there's very little variety. Especially in the Mega+ Digimon, some things like X-Antibody are missing completely. It wouldn't be that big of a deal if at least the existing Digimon were different but they aren't, which means you are going for the same end-game you went for in the previous games. Nothing new or exciting. This yet again makes it worse because even if you get to the NG+ & Mega+ there's nothing to play it for but the challenge.

- Bad Sidequest distribution. During the game you will get 1-2 sidequests in every area, which you can finish if a matter of minutes. This pace remains until right before the end where the game dumps like 20+ sidequests on you. It would be much nicer if they'd spread them out more evenly.

- Card Battles. This is just a disgrace and slap in the face for anyone who ever like any mini-game ever. This is a horrible rock-paper-scissor game that's affected by pure RNG. Straight up worst mini-game I've ever played. It's all the worse considering that Digimon World 3 had the whole Digimon Trading Card Game in it, even though it was somehow reduced and the turn were pre-determined. I sincerely hope whoever made this and approved this gets fired. The game would be better off without it, as it will just make you disappointed or angry.

- Farm is bad. Besides the issues of how much stronger it can make you very easily it straight up looks worse than Cyber Sleuth or even Dusk/Dawn. It has some customization element that's purely cosmetic but what is even the point when it looks so bad and does nothing? As if that's not bad enough some items for it are paid DLC, which does literally nothing.

- Monetization. This is overall pretty expensive game. 70‚Ç¨/$ is a lot for some people. I don't feel like you're getting your buck's worth out of it and what's worse is the atrocious DLCs. Day 1 DLCs are a tragedy, even more-so when you have DLCs that aren't included in the most expensive version of the game. Yet another spit in the face for paying customers. And what do you get out of it? Random farm items that do absolutely nothing nor look good. Two Digimon (Black Agumon/Black Gabumon) that you can get easily and almost immediately. This is supposed to be worth IRL money when you actually paid already? Or paying for OSTs from previous games/anime series? Absolutely ridiculous. Don't get me started on the P2W dungeons that you can only access if you buy them. Yes, you don't have to buy them but just the fact that we got to a point where single player games have this is beyond me.

- Outer Dungeons. I don't have problem with all of them or the concept in general. They are ok, but eventually you get few specific dungeons where you fight the ''Strongest'' Digimons. I assume this is meant to be some kind of challenge dungeons. This is where the problem is, not only are they really easy you have to rewards for them. No items, no money, no special item, achievement, nothing. Just a waste of time and disappointment.

- Denuvo. Perhaps the most egregious overstep. What can I say besides that no developer who ever includes Denuvo in their game ever deserves any money. Just another big ''Screw you'' to the paying customer. This would warrant bad rating on it's own, though the game gives me plenty other reasons to do it anyways.

Ultimately I feel like this game has great core and potential that was stomped to the ground by bad decisions and corporate greed. I absolutely wouldn't recommend financially supporting games like this, otherwise nothing will ever change.

This review is mostly for people who like difficult games and actually want their choices to feel like they matter in an RPG. I‚Äôm not gonna go over the usual positives or the fact that it‚Äôs a turn-based JRPG, which I like. So I'm happy the game is doing well but a lot of reviews just ignore the downsides.

The DLC and monetization are pretty scummy. Overpriced and DLC stages are just easy XP/money farms.

The game feels really low budget. You can even notice it in the demo if you wanna check before buying, Itt feels like it should be $20 cheaper.

Currently at launch there's tons of bugs some that softlocks and forces you to either wait for a fix/mod or reload an old save. The game just feels like it had bad testing

Difficulty options are really bad. Previous games like Cyber Sleuth and Hacker‚Äôs Memory had hard modes that actually mattered. Here, ‚Äúhard‚Äù barely changes anything. Dataminers say it only gives enemies 20% more ATK and INT, everything else is the same. Compare that to Cyber Sleuth where stats doubled, or Hacker‚Äôs Memory where it was 1.5x.

The common response I see? ‚ÄúJust play on Mega or Mega+‚Äù that‚Äôs for NG+, not a first playthrough. I wanted a hard first experience. There's no harm in that you don't have to choose it, I don't want a boring Pokemon feeling in turn based RPG games.

Right now you can ignore a lot of mechanics and still auto-battle bosses on hard because the game is just too easy. It feels like a Pok√©mon game where nothing you do matters, I could basically mash my keyboard (or controller) and win every fight.

Balance overall is bad. The game gives players a ton of advantages and new mechanics to get stronger while also making enemies weaker compared to the previous two games. The loading system completely breaks balance you can feed fodder Digimon to one and have it carry you through the whole game. They nerfed it a bit in day 1 patch from the demo I believe, but it‚Äôs still way too strong.

The Agent Tree is too strong too. You can give a Digimon the right personality and get like 75% extra stats. But honestly‚Ä¶ do you even need it? The game is already too easy, so it feels pointless. No real satisfaction.

Lots of QoL stuff is missing too:

*You can‚Äôt evolve in the farm, have to take them out first

*Feeding in the farm is slow, clunky, and annoying

*Paying to fast-forward training should at least scale with how much time is left, but it doesn‚Äôt

At its core, the game just feels outdated. It‚Äôs way too similar to vita games like Cyber Sleuth and doesn‚Äôt feel like a proper upgrade for the price and year.

At this state I put the game down and started waiting for a difficulty mod.

I really wanted to like this game but the flaws are just too big to ignore. I've practically played every Digimon game with an english translation so far, and sadly Time Stranger is on the weaker side. Its saving grace is that it is the only Digimon game we're gonna get for another 5 years probably.

The good parts first:
- We actually get a digital world this time.
- I really like the big city in the Digital World. It feels lively.
- Big Digimon roster
- Nice signature move animations

Problems:
- The game was clearly rushed. Especially nearing the end this gets more and more evident. The story is skipping some parts. The animations get very barebone. The majority of side quests unlock just before the final boss, indicating that they were finished before the parts in the story where they belonged.
- The story is badly written and boring. Expecting a good story for a digimon game might be overkill, but it makes up the biggest part of the game in Time Stranger.
- Too many badly written human characters, who you are forced to interact with for dozens of hours.
- You have very little freedom in the game because the time travel story often locks you into certain areas.
- Way too much time is wasted outside the digital world.
- No real "digimon feel" after the first few areas in the digital world.
- No postgame.
- Most of the game is spent on auto battle at 5x speed (at least for me). Manual battle is too tedious for trash mobs. If you know your game has tedious trash mob encounters, you should rethink your design instead of adding high speed auto battling as a bandaid.
- The personality system actively hinders you from digivolving your partners across the entire digivolution grid. It's much easier to just get a new digimon with the correct personality for a digivolution line than it is for you to make your long time partner into the digimon you want.
- Costs 70 bucks despite being unfinished
- Lots of unnecessary and overpriced DLC

tl;dr:
Only buy if you really need a Digimon game, no matter the quality. This game was rushed despite the 10 years since Cyber Sleuth and you can feel it. Despite that, Bandai charges 70 bucks for it. The story and the characters are bad and take up the majority of the game. Exploring the Digital World feels like an afterthought.

Initially thought it was a great sequel to Cyber Sleuth (bought on several systems, but several hundreds hours in to) but the more you get into the systems the clunkier they feel. The story is good and the and the game, especially the digimon themselves are looking great, however things feel bottle-necked to push you into DLC's to speed up obtaining currency/xp/etc. 

The trait system is a pain to micromanage with no ability to set a 'target' so you're constantly having to double check what dialogue choices you need to make to get traits where you want them, especially if you're working on several digimon at once. This is coupled with the descriptions around the trait system being different to the actual terms used in the table itself, which all just adds to the general feeling of clunkiness. 

I'm still enjoying it, but its beginning to wear thin and its wildly overpriced for a game that feels inferior to the predecessor gameplay-wise.

[h1]The Digimon Game that Made Me Give Up on Digimon Games.[/h1]

I've always struggled with sticking to modern Digimon games as they often are plagued with a slew of problems that they've latched onto for nostalgia-baiting purposes. Time Stranger steps away from that time honored tradition that Digimon Games follow and tries to set itself apart and cater to NEW players who might have an interest in the game. Unfortunately whilst Time Stranger sets itself apart from other Digimon games, the game just isn't particularly that great, and if you've played any generic turn-based RPG from the early 2000's or even now you've basically played it. Admittedly I've tried SO HARD to like this game as it does stand apart from other Digimon games, but the experience is either largely bland or bad for the majority of the game to the point that I can't bring myself to continue wasting time playing it.

Furthermore there seems to be this.. Overall consensus that a large portion of the community has regarding this game which is that "It gets good around the 25-30 hour mark", and admittedly I find that to be insanity. In our world where there's an ever-growing supply of games which can be FUN and ENGAGING from the first 5 minutes, why spend your time on something which isn't fantastic from the first step? Are the standards of people playing this game so astronomically low that they think this is ok? Even the #1 Review AT CURRENT says the game is essentially boring/mid yet rates it positively due to it being A DIGIMON GAME.

There's so many things in this game that make it obvious that the game is half-baked like there only being basically 5 voice actors for all the Digimon when they attack - I sincerely hope you like the voice of in-game Agumon because it's possible to have 15 different Digimon you use which have the same voice! Time Strangers' marketing paints the game as having these grandiose and beautiful overworld areas, but all these are is cleverly disguised hallways and linear paths. 

Time Strangers' gameplay is overall boring and so badly wants to be mechanically deep and interesting yet doesn't give you enough tools for that to be the case and restricts your actual usage of tactics. Gameplay for the game quickly devolves into "Does your Digimon have the type which is resistant to the enemy? No? Do you have Convert?". Almost every single attack in the game is basically just a reskin of every other single attack in the game, and bosses being resistant to most statuses means that the only real "tactical gameplay" to be had is just whether you debuff them or not. 

Time Strangers' view of difficulty seems to be confused for annoyance, with the bosses not even being hard to take on within the hard difficulty. Boss fight formula in this game is essentially the boss pulling some dumb bullshit out of nowhere repeatedly to *TRY* to make the fights require you to think, yet they still devolve into using three Digimon which are resistant to the boss and nothing more because you're not given any other options than to buff and sweep.

Time Strangers' story is extremely predictable and almost all of the characters just feel so unlikable within the storyline, with constant terrible and predictable choices plaguing the narrative to the point it feels like your stereotypical shonen anime. On top of this the progression system feels incredibly padded to make it to where you're FORCED to spend more time playing the game to Digivolve anything to a Digimon you might actually care about. Time Strangers' Agent Rank system is admittedly worse than the grinding system in CyberSleuth which already wasn't great. 

Go play something else which is fun from the start.
